title: Legal related inquiries + Lawyer/Court fees
content: Table of Content ​ Customer requests with legal positions involved Process flows Complaint: customer did not received return/pick up date Complaint: customer did not received refund Complaint: about product/logistic claim of customer Any legal advice from customers Lawyer fees Guidelines for reporting legal notifications, letters and inquiries ​ Customer requests with legal positions involved Most of the requests are complaints based on the history of the communication between Agent and customer. After reading the inquiry (and pre communication!), it is very important to find out, how to help the customer/lawyer in the easiest way as possible. What are the more common requests? - Refunds - Returns - Claims - Legal advices (always use the formal templates form L&C) Most requests from lawyers are because of earlier customer experience with the Emma customer service. It is important to note that if you encounter a mistake on our team's or the customer's part, do not fingerpoint on someone because our concern is not to "put the blame" on anyone, but to resolve the customer's concern with high satisfaction. Process flows: -> Please note that this article does not replace the individual steps involved in handling customer inquiries, but only instructs how to respond to a legal position in the given cases. ​ ​ Complaint: customer did not received return/pick up date 1st step: Read communication history + check order in Magento 2nd step: If no return is received, please process as given in Knowledge Base article for return according to your country. Sometimes the customer already got pick up dates but however they did not work out (mostly because of us). Please make sure that the return is set correctly in Magento (see: Return Requests ) 3rd step: After making sure, that there is a fixed pick-up date that the customer can rely on, inform the lawyer that the refund will be made as a result of the return and that the proof of return should be withdrawn. Mandatory: Use on of given templates to answer: Legal requests - Return info (to lawyer) Legal requests - Pick up info (to lawyer) Complaint: customer did not received refund 1st step: Read communication history + check order in Magento 2nd step: If no refund is processed, please check the refund conditions according to your country (return received, tracking number provided, e.g.) and process as given in Knowledge Base article for refunds (see: Refund requests ) 3rd step: If return is already received, you can process the refund for the affected item. 4th step: If refund is already done, please provide lawyer proof of refund (also see: Refund requests ) Mandatory: Use template to answer: Legal requests - Refund info (to lawyer) ​ Relevant links: Product Refund Central Europe ​ ​ Complaint: Lawyer contact us about product/logistic claim of customer 1st step: Read communication history, check order in Magento 2nd step: Check KB article about product/logistic claim to proceed as given according to your country (e.g.: create claim in magento, ask for photos of products etc) 3rd step: If there is a need to give the customer a compensation and it exceeds your limit, please escalate to your supervisor to let them decide how much to refund the customer. 4th step: Mandatory: Use one of given template Legal requests - Product claim (to lawyer) Legal requests - Logistic claim (to lawyer) Compensation Matrix - European markets Customer asks for legal advice 1st step: Please check if the customers request is based on a legal problem, which can not be handled without help of Legal&Compliance. 2nd step: If so, only than you can open a L&C Jira ticket. Do not forgot to put in all relevant information for the case and the customer in the ticket. Please note that L&C can only help in giving advice, but will not take on the whole case. Also mind when escalating to L&C to translate the inquiry in English. 3rd step: Wait for response of L&C and forward received information to customer. NOTE: No escalations from Freshdesk anymore! Please do not put L&Cs email address in any notes or do not escalate the ticket to L&C through Freshdesk. Lawyer + Court fees IMPORTANT : - ALWAYS PROCE SS THE REFUND FOR LAWYER FEES FROM REFUNDS AND NOT FROM THE ORDER . - ONLY PROCEED WITH THE REFUND FOR LAWYER FEES AFTER THE WHOLE CASE IS SOLVED . Escalation guildeline: Up to 800 EUR: Need approval from supervisor Up to 1000 EUR: Need approval from Emma Intern (CECE Managers) From 1000 EUR: Need approval from Legal&Compliance After getting approval from Supervisor / CE Manager / L&C escalate , as usually , to Refunds. NOTE: Please note that we mostly receive requests from lawyers in PDF format, so it is important to read this carefully; These documents can be sometimes too complicated to understand due to formalities, so asking for assistance is not a problem; Lawyer fees: Always refund the lawyer fees after the whole case is solved; If you do not understand the content of one of these documents you can also use the same forwarding macro to forward the inquiry to L&C and ask for support. Important: Legal will tell you what the issue is and whether you should review the refund, return, claim, etc. L&C will not take over the ticket. After that you can process normally as given in this article. ​ Guidelines for reporting legal notifications, letters and inquiries When an agent receives any notification from an entity (e.g., courts, criminal authorities, law enforcement, public prosecutors, public or private entities, and so on) related to data breaches or legal inquiries (e.g. court letters, requests from police or other government agencies, etc.), it must be immediately forwarded to the Legal and Compliance Team (“L&C Team”). If you are unsure whether to notify the L&C Team, here are some examples of notifications that need to be notified of to the L&C Team: “Notice – Court Summons” Public Prosecutor Inquiry Regarding Consumer Claims” “Claim for Damages from XXXX” “Notice of Pending Class Action Lawsuit” “Investigation Notice from Law Enforcement” “Investigation by Public Authorities Regarding XXXXX” “Legal Demand Letter Regarding Breach of Contract” “Request for Legal Opinion on Privacy Policy Compliance” “Urgent: Regulatory Compliance Issue for Immediate Review” “Tax Investigation or Audit Notice” “Notice of Investigation / Inquiry by a Data Protection Authority” Therefore, the actions required when a notification is received are: Notify L&C immediately by sending an email to legalcompliance@emma-sleep.com AND providing in the email all relevant details and documentation related to the notification, including the nature of the inquiry or data breach, and the ACTUAL document from the sender. DO NOT DIRECTLY REPLY TO THE AUTHORITY/SENDER . IMPORTANT NOTE: Inquiries and/or reports related to data breach/security incidents must be sent to privacy@emma-sleep.com , following the guidelines previously shared. This process ensures that legal matters are handled promptly, and that EMMA remains compliant with the applicable laws and regulations.

title: GDPR and DSRs: What is it?
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Rights Under GDPR: Data Subject Request (DSR) General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) GDPR stands for General Data Protection Regulation. It is a regulation in EU law on data protection and privacy in the European Union and the European Economic Area. The GDPR is an important component of EU privacy law and of human rights law, in particular Article 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. More specifically, GDPR is supposed to prevent businesses and organisations from misusing personal data from their customers. At Emma protecting our customers' data is always a priority. Rights Under GDPR: Data Subject Request (DSR) The GDPR provides some rights to customers regarding their data privacy. Those rights are called Data Subject Requests (DSRs). Emma customers can request their rights if they ever feel like Emma is being negligent with their data or simply for personal reasons. To comply with EU GDPR when processing personal data Emma must follow these basic principles:

title: GDPR: Handling Customers' Requests
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS How to Identify a GDPR Request: What to do when you receive a GDPR request from a Customer? How to Identify a GDPR Request: Customer service often receives DSR (data subject rights) requests. When someone asks about their personal information and what they want to do with it, it probably be a DSR. These requests are like specific messages where people ask for things like seeing their data, deleting it, or stopping Emma from using it in certain ways. Identifying a DSR request also means recognizing when someone is asking about their rights under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Below you can find the link for the articles related to the DSR Requests that a CS agent may receive: GDPR: Right to object/oppose GDPR: Right to delete/erasure GDPR: Right to access GDPR: Right to portability GDPR: Right to restrict/limit GDPR: Right to rectify /correct What to do when you receive a GDPR request from a Customer? If you receive other GDPR requests, you should immediately forward it to the email: privacy@emma-sleep.com. Don’t forget to send the canned acknowledgment reply to the customer. Make sure you properly tag a GDPR ticket if it is really related to personal data and data protection. Step 1: Forward the request to Legal & Compliance (except if the request is Right to rectify/correct order data) If you receive the request via Freshdesk, chat, email, call or face-to-face please forward the request right away to: privacy@emma-sleep.com The Legal & Compliance team will reply to the DSR. Step 2: Reply to the Customer using Canned Response Suggested Response to Reply: Dear (Customer's first name), Thank you for your inquiry regarding personal data. We have forwarded your request to our Data Protection team, and they will reply to you in due course. Thank you, Your Emma Team ATTENTION: Mandatory for marketing unsubscribe requests If you receive a request to be unsubscribed/opposing from marketing , don’t forget to add this in your DSR acknowledgment response: “If you have received a marketing communication of Emma products and wish to opt out from receiving it, please reply to this e-mail including the communication as an attachment. Although this is not obligatory, we will be able to identify the sender more easily and communicate your intention to opt out more quickly.”

title: GDPR: Right to Access
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS What is the Right to Access? Examples How to handle requests for "Right to Access"? REVIEW: To check all articles related to the GDPR topic, please read "Security Protocols & GDPR: Overview" ATTENTION: First, read the article " GDPR: Handling Customers' Requests" to verify all options for DSR requests. What is the Right to Access? The "right to access" means that individuals can ask to see what personal data a company has about them and how it's being used. For example, if someone requests a copy of their personal data or if they want to know what information Emma has collected about them, they are exercising their right to access. In this case, you must forward the data subject request to privacy@emma-sleep.com. Examples: John never bought Emma products nor registered to receive Emma’s newsletters but receives marketing communications from Emma. He is curious about the personal data Emma has collected about him over the years. He submits a request to the customer service asking for a copy of all the information Emma has about him, including advertising preferences. Daniel has been a customer of your online sleep products store for some time. He's curious about the personal data Emma collected about him and how it's being used for marketing purposes. Daniel submits a request to customer service to provide him with a detailed report of his account activity, including his purchase history and any marketing preferences he might have provided. Other examples of access requests you may receive: “Can I see what data you have about me?" This is a request to access personal data, which is one of the rights under GDPR. They want to know what information we have about them and how we're using it. "I'm curious about the information your company has about me. Could you please provide a detailed report of my account activity and personal data?" This request is a general inquiry from a customer who wants to know what information the company has collected about them. "I suspect that there may be errors in my personal data stored by your company. Can I request access to review and correct any inaccuracies?" This request is from a user who wants to review their personal data for accuracy and potentially correct any errors they find. "I'm considering using your services but would like more information about how my personal data will be used. Can you provide a summary of the data you collect and how it's processed?" This request is from a prospective customer who wants transparency about the company's data practices before engaging with their services. "I recently made a purchase from your online store and would like to access my order history and account details for my records." This request is from a customer who wants to access their past purchase history and account information from the company's online store. "I want to understand how my personal data is being used for targeted advertising by your company. Could you please provide me with a summary of the data collected and how it's used for advertising purposes?" This request is from a user who wants to know how their personal data is used for targeted advertising on the company's platform. How to handle requests for "Right to Access"? Step 1: Forward the request to Legal & Compliance If you receive the request via Freshdesk, chat, email, call or face-to-face please forward the request right away to: privacy@emma-sleep.com The Legal & Compliance team will reply to the DSR. Step 2: Reply to the Customer using Canned Response Suggested Response to Reply: Dear (Customer's first name), Thank you for your inquiry regarding personal data. We have forwarded your request to our Data Protection team, and they will reply to you in due course. Thank you, Your Emma Team

title: GDPR: Right to Delete/Erasure
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS What is the Right to Delete/Erasure? Example How to handle requests for "Right to Delete/Erasure"? REVIEW: To check all articles related to the GDPR topic, please read "Security Protocols & GDPR: Overview" ATTENTION: First, read the article " GDPR: Handling Customers' Requests" to verify all options for DSR requests. What is the Right to Delete/Erasure? The "right to delete" means that individuals can ask to have their personal data deleted from a company's records. For example, if someone requests that their account be deleted from a website, or if they ask for specific information about them to be removed from a database, they are exercising their right to delete. Example: Imagine Sarah, who registered in an online shopping website, decides she no longer wants her account with them. She contacts the company and requests that they delete all her personal information, including her purchase history and saved payment details, from their system. In this case, you must forward the data subject request to privacy@emma-sleep.com . Other examples of right to erasure/deletion requests you may receive: "Please delete my account and all my information." This is a request for erasure, another right under GDPR. They're asking us to get rid of all their personal data from our systems. "I accidentally provided incorrect information when signing up. Please delete my account so I can create a new one with accurate details." This request is from a user who wants their account deleted in order to start fresh with correct information. "I no longer wish to be associated with your company and request that all my personal data be permanently removed." This request is from a user who wants the deletion of all their personal data. "I received an email from your company but have never signed up for your service. Please remove any information you have associated with my email address." This request is from someone who received unsolicited communication from the company and wants their information removed from the company's records. "I was notified of a data breach involving your company, and I'm concerned about the security of my personal information. Please delete my account and all associated data as a precaution." This request is from a user who wants their data deleted due to concerns about data security following a reported breach. How to handle requests for "Right to Delete/Erasure"? Step 1: Forward the request to Legal & Compliance If you receive the request via Sprinklr, chat, email, call or face-to-face please forward the request right away to: privacy@emma-sleep.com The Legal & Compliance team will reply to the DSR. Step 2: Reply to the Customer using Canned Response Suggested Response to Reply: Dear (Customer's first name), Thank you for your inquiry regarding personal data. We have forwarded your request to our Data Protection team, and they will reply to you in due course. Thank you, Your Emma Team

title: GDPR: Right to Limit/Restrict
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS What is the Right to Limit/Restrict? Examples and how to handle How to handle requests for "Right to Limit/Restrict"? REVIEW: To check all articles related to the GDPR topic, please read "Security Protocols & GDPR: Overview" ATTENTION: First, read the article " GDPR: Handling Customers' Requests" to verify all options for DSR requests. What is the Right to Limit/Restrict? The "right to limit" means that individuals can request restrictions on the processing of their personal data under certain circumstances. For example, if someone asks Emma to stop processing their data for targeted advertising, they are exercising their right to limit. Examples and how to handle: Example 1: Michael has been receiving targeted ads from Emma based on his browsing history. He finds these ads intrusive and requests that the retailer stops using his data for personalized advertising. As a result, Emma agrees to only show him generic ads instead. Example 2: A customer who says: "I'm currently involved in a legal dispute with your company and request that you limit the processing of my personal data until the matter is resolved. Please refrain from using my data for any purposes unrelated to the ongoing legal proceedings." This request is from someone involved in a legal dispute with the company who wants to limit the processing of their personal data until the matter is resolved. title: GDPR: Right to Object or to Oppose (marketing communications)
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS What is the Right to Object or to Oppose (to marketing communications):? Example: How to handle requests for "Right to Object or to Oppose"? REVIEW: To check all articles related to the GDPR topic, please read "Security Protocols & GDPR: Overview" ATTENTION: First, read the article " GDPR: Handling Customers' Requests" to verify all options for DSR requests. What is the Right to Object or to Oppose (to marketing communications):? The "right to object" to marketing means that people can say they don't want to receive certain types of marketing messages. For example, if someone asks not to get any more emails promoting products or services, that's them exercising their right to object to marketing. Similarly, if they request to stop receiving phone calls, texts, or any other form of marketing communication, that's them using their right to object. In this case, you must forward the data subject request to privacy@emma-sleep.com . Example: To give an example, Alice has been receiving marketing emails not only from our online sleep products store but also from third-party companies promoting Emma’s products. However, she finds these emails irrelevant and wishes to stop receiving them. Alice contacts the customer service and specifically requests to opt-out of marketing communications (from Emma’s or from third parties on Emma’s behalf), asking that her personal data not be shared with any third-party companies for marketing purposes. Other examples of right to oppose requests you may receive: I've been getting a lot of emails from your company, but I don't want them anymore. Please stop sending me marketing emails." This is a clear request to oppose marketing. The person doesn't want to receive any more promotional emails from our company. "I'm receiving too many promotional emails from your company. Could you please unsubscribe me from your mailing list?" This is a request to unsubscribe from our mailing list, which is a way of opposing marketing. They want to stop receiving promotional emails. "I'm tired of getting emails about your products from this third party. Please remove ask them to remove me from the mailing list. I do not want to receive emails from your products anymore" Similar to the previous example, this is a request to be removed from a third-party mailing list to stop receiving marketing emails. "I don't want to receive any more emails promoting your products. Can you make sure of it? This is another request to be removed from our marketing list to stop receiving promotional emails. "Please ask your company not to send me any more email marketing. I don't want to hear about your products anymore." This is a direct request to the recipient to take action on behalf of our company, asking them to stop receiving email marketing from us. "Please don't share my information with other companies for advertising." This is also a request to oppose marketing, specifically third-party marketing. They're asking us not to share their data with other companies for advertising purposes. How to handle requests for "Right to Object or to Oppose"? Step 1: Forward the request to Legal & Compliance If you receive the request via Freshdesk, chat, email, call or face-to-face please forward the request right away to: privacy@emma-sleep.com The Legal & Compliance team will reply to the DSR. Step 2: Reply to the Customer using Canned Response Suggested Response to Reply: Dear (Customer's first name), Thank you for your inquiry regarding personal data. We have forwarded your request to our Data Protection team, and they will reply to you in due course. Thank you, Your Emma Team ATTENTION: Mandatory for marketing unsubscribe requests If you receive a request to be unsubscribed/opposing from marketing , don’t forget to add this in your DSR acknowledgment response: “If you have received a marketing communication of Emma products and wish to opt out from receiving it, please reply to this e-mail including the communication as an attachment. Although this is not obligatory, we will be able to identify the sender more easily and communicate your intention to opt out more quickly.”

title: GDPR: Right to Portability
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS What is the Right to Portability? Examples How to handle requests for "Right to Portability"? What is the Right to Portability? The "right to data portability" means that individuals can request to receive their personal data in a commonly used and machine-readable format, and in some cases, to have it transferred to another organization. Examples: Example 1: Sophie has been purchasing sleep products from our online store but wants to explore other options for better deals. She requests her personal data, including her purchase history and product preferences, from our store in a format that she can easily transfer to another sleep products retailer's system to receive personalized offers. Example 2: "Can you give me a copy of my data so I can move it to another service?" This is a request for data portability. They want their personal data in a format they can take with them to another company. How to handle requests for "Right to Portability"? Step 1: Forward the request to Legal & Compliance If you receive the request via Freshdesk, chat, email, call or face-to-face please forward the request right away to: privacy@emma-sleep.com The Legal & Compliance team will reply to the DSR. title: GDPR: Right to Rectify/Correct
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS What is the Right to Rectify/Correct? Example Other scenarios Name Correction Address Update Phone Number Correction Email Address Change Billing Information Update How to handle requests for "Right to Rectify/Correct"? REVIEW: To check all articles related to the GDPR topic, please read "Security Protocols & GDPR: Overview" ATTENTION: First, read the article " GDPR: Handling Customers' Requests" to verify all options for DSR requests. What is the Right to Rectify/Correct? The "right to correct" means that individuals have the right to update or correct inaccurate or incomplete personal data held by organizations about them. This right ensures that people can maintain the accuracy and integrity of their personal information. Example: Let's say John recently purchased a mattress online from Emma. During the checkout process, he accidentally entered the wrong delivery address. After completing the order, he realizes the mistake and contacts the Emma’s customer service to correct the address. John exercises his right to correct by informing Emma of the inaccurate delivery address and requesting that it be updated to the correct one. Other scenarios: Let's check other examples of access requests you may receive: Name Correction: "Hello, I recently made a purchase on your online store, but I noticed that my name is misspelled on the order confirmation email. Could you please correct my name to 'John Smith' instead of 'Jon Smith'?" Address Update: "Hi there, I recently moved to a new address, and I need to update it in my account information. My current address is [Old Address], but I'd like to change it to [New Address]. Could you please update it for me?" Phone Number Correction: "Hello, I've noticed that my phone number is incorrect in my account details. The correct number is [Correct Phone Number]. Could you please update it accordingly?" Email Address Change: "Hi, I've recently changed my email address and I need to update it in my account settings. My new email address is [New Email Address]. Can you please make this change for me?" Billing Information Update: "Good afternoon, I've noticed that the billing information associated with my recent mattress purchase is outdated. Could you please update it to reflect my current billing address: [New Billing Address]?" In each of these examples, the individual is exercising their right to rectify by requesting corrections or updates to their personal information held by the company. This ensures that their data is accurate and up to date, which is essential for smooth transactions and effective communication. How to handle requests for "Right to Rectify/Correct"? The Data Protection Team is technically unable to modify order information, so please directly handle this data correction request (e.g. you modify the information as requested on the order information by yourself) and respond to the customer within 15 days from the date of their request . Once you have completed and responded to the request, please send a confirmation to the requesting customer (you may use the template response below ). You do not need to forward order information correction/rectification requests to the Data Protection Team. We will only receive notification if you do not address the data correction request after 15 days. Sample response: Thank you for your email. We have received your request to correct your personal data in our system. We would like to inform you that we have updated your order information as requested.

title: GDPR: What is Personal Data?
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS What is Personal Data? How GDPR impacst our work as CS in Emma? REVIEW: To check all articles related to the GDPR topic, please read "Security Protocols & GDPR: Overview" What is Personal Data? When customers make a purchase at Emma Websites or contact our customer service regarding their orders, they are required to share some personal information with Emma, for example, name, address, email, etc. This information is called Personal Data. Although personal data can be divided into 2 types: Personal Data: Name, identification number, telephone number, order related information, for example. Sensitive Personal Data: personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs; trade-union membership; genetic data, biometric data processed solely to identify a human being; health-related data; data concerning a person’s sex life or sexual orientation. How GDPR impacts our work as CS in Emma? As an agent, you are responsible for all the information shared by the customer while handling an interaction, in other words, while handling a ticket (phone call, email, or even chat). A agent should only deal with the Personal Data of the customer which are relevant and requested in our procedures. A agent should NEVER make comments or leave notes with Sensitive Personal Data from our customers.

title: Security Protocol: Customer Identification
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS Identification factors How do we identify the customer? Call recording Third-party verification Third-party verification - Death/Bereavement Identification factors For any customer contact (phone, email, and chat) in which the customer requests information on their Emma account, information or action on an existing order, we should never confirm the existence of the order or provide any information to the customer, concerning the order or the account, until the customer's identity has been verified. However, if the customer is contacting us via email and the email address being used is the same as the one used to place the order with us, then we can consider the customer automatically authenticated. Additionally, we can change this information in the Order Management System (Magento or FluentCommerce), but we need to make sure that we authenticated the customer first, using three additional factors, excluding the one we will be amending. So, for example, if the customer wants to change the email address connected to the order we must authenticate him/her first using three of the following five elements: name under which the order was placed, order number, delivery address or phone number. How do we identify the customer? ​ We must match 3 i dentification factors , before giving any information or acting on an existing order. ​ Those factors are important to verify the customer's identity before acting on their requests. This will avoid disclosing data to a party that is not entitled to it and also potential fraud. Name under which the order was placed (do not confuse this with the name under the billing or shipping addresses) Email address used to place the order Order number Delivery address Telephone number included in the billing address It is necessary to leave a note ( Yes / No / N/A ) in Magento for each customer contact if the identity has been verified: Yes : Identity successfully verified with at least 3 matching identification factors from the order. No : Identity could not be verified - could not proceed with the request. N/A : Identification was not necessary. Verification is not necessary for requests that do not relate to an order or a customer account. IMPORTANT: We should not ask a customer to provide us with any additional authentication factors after they have given us 3 valid ones. After this is done, if we continue to ask for more authentication factors, we are blocking the customer's access to information that they are at this point legally entitled to. Third-party verification ​ If a third party contacts us requesting information/action on an order that he/she did not place themselves, we may NOT give out any info in the first instance. IMPORTANT If police officers or lawyers contact us regarding an order or a customer account, information is not allowed to be provided on the phone or via chat. Phone Contact: We ask third parties to put the person who placed the order on the phone, verify his/her identity, and proactively ask for their authorisation to talk about the order with the third party. If the customer is not there, they must contact us themselves by email or by phone at a later time to request the information in question. Alternatively, during the phone call, we can send an email to the email address that the customer left in their order without providing said email address to the person contacting us on the phone. Chat Contact: If the person contacting us identifies himself/herself as the customer that placed the order and correctly provides 3 identification factors, we proceed with the contact. However, if the person contacting us via chat identifies himself/herself as someone else, we then have two alternatives. Either that person provides a written authorization letter (CE_Authorization Letter, file attached to this article) signed by the customer that placed the order, allowing us to talk and disclose information to the current requester (wife, son, friend, etc) or we ask to be contacted using the email address that was used to place the order (which will bypass any need for further authentication. Email Contact: If the contact is coming from the email address that was used to place the order on OMS, even if it is signed by someone else, we can proceed and do not require further authentication. However, i f the person is contacting us using a different email address than the one that was used to place the order, the agents should ask the customer to contact us using the email address that was used to place the order and tell the customer that, if that is no longer possible, they should provide us their name (as present in the order), the order number and the email address used to place the order, so that we are able to assist further. Third-party verification in cases of death/bereavement For verification purposes, in cases of bereavement the person contacting only needs to provide the 3 authentication factors, following the same process as if it was the customer contacting us (No relationship documentation is needed). However in case changes are requested, e.g.: customer wants to have the receipt sent to another email. We will require the customer to provide a death certificate for the person that originally placed the order. Again no relationship document is needed. Once you have received a valid death certificate you can proceed with the change requested and afterwards the document (death certificate) will need to be deleted. Death certificate is needed only for due diligence and is deleted as soon as possible. docx Authorization letter.docx 0.01 MB
