title: Light x Temperature: Which factor impacts our sleep the most?
content: The physical elements that interfere the most with our sleep are light and temperature . We know how light and a particular frequency of light can generate excitatory effects, inhibiting melatonin production and making us feel more alert and less willing to sleep. A legitimate question in this respect is: which element, between light and temperature, can influence our sleep routines the most? It is generally believed that in pre-industrial societies, the sleep of our ancestors was exclusively linked to the alternation of day and night. For this reason, many believe that in tribes and communities that lived without electricity, sleep coincided with sunset and awakening with sunrise. And for many years, this belief was also shared by academics. In 2015, however, a scientific research article entitled Natural Sleep and Its Seasonal Variations in Three Pre-industrial Societies was published in the leading scientific journal Current Biology . This article shows the results of a study conducted on three indigenous populations and attempts to answer the following question: How did humans sleep before the modern era? The answer to this question may help us to clarify the importance of light and temperature for our sleep. It has been argued that the invention of the electric light, followed by the development of television, the Internet, and related technologies, along with increased caffeine usage, has dramatically shortened sleep duration from ‘‘natural’’ levels and disrupted its evolved timing. Is it true? The researchers argue that: Light may not be as crucial for sleep patter as previously believed. The difference in sleep duration between our industrialized society and the pre-industrial one is not that great. The indigenous people have fewer sleep concerns when compared to post-industrial societies. Temperature plays a significant role in defining our sleep patterns. The experiment concerned three tribes: Hadza from Tanzania, Tsimane from Bolivia, and San from Namibia. In these societies, electricity and its associated lighting and entertainment distractions are absent, as are cooling and heating systems . Notably, none of these groups began sleep near sunset, with sleep onset occurring, on average, 3.3 hr after twilight. This shows how the rest of ancient societies were not synchronized with the alternation between night and day. On the contrary, the sleep period consistently occurred during the nighttime period of falling environmental temperature . It terminated, with vasoconstriction, near the lowest point of daily ambient temperature. For this reason, the researcher concluded that the daily cycle of temperature change, largely eliminated from modern sleep environments, can be a potent natural regulator of sleep . Another element that was researched was insomnia. Since it is a complaint that does not closely correlate to sleep, researchers evaluated the incidence of this complaint. The tribal population does not have a name for insomnia in their language. 5% of the participants indicated they occasionally had sleep onset issues. 5% sometimes had sleep maintenance problems. Less than 1/3 of these people reported that they experienced these issues frequently, i.e., more than once a year (1.5 percent and 2.5 percent of the total number of participants). These values are significantly lower than the 10–30 percent chronic insomnia rate observed in industrial cultures. For what concerns light: Moreover, the three groups regularly had tiny fires. The research also showed that waking occurred on average 1 hour before dawn; This fact supports the belief that sleep wasn't strongly connected to solar light. For what concerns temperature: Let’s now analyze the impact of temperature . The researchers discovered that the nocturnal sleep phase in the indigenous people was always beginning at declining ambient temperature. Therefore, they accurately monitored ambient temperature coupled with finger temperature and stomach temperature at the sleeping places. The results demonstrate that sleep in both the winter and summer occurred during declining ambient temperature and that awakenings happened towards the lowest point of the daily temperature cycle. Why is this very relevant for us? We can learn from this article the importance that temperature plays on the regularity of our sleep . Contrary to earlier belief, it is not only light that plays a central role in our biological rhythms. Temperature is an even more potent synchronizer than light itself. As proof of this, the study cited above shows that our sleeping and waking rhythms coincide precisely with the lowering and raising of atmospheric temperature. For this reason, we can use this knowledge to reinforce the idea that the correct temperature is fundamental to the quality of our sleep. In particular, our customer should not only take care to have a bedroom as free as possible of electronic gadgets that emit blue-light but, equally (if not more), they should take care to have a temperature difference in their bedroom that makes it easier for us to fall asleep. Moreover, this study shows the importance of technologies that ensure the natural decrease in body temperature in conjunction with sleep, such as a mattress with superior thermal properties. Knowing the importance of sleep, at Emma, we develop products with this in mind. The Diamond Degree mattress is designed to ensure the perfect temperature for your sleep . It is made of a particular layer of foam called Energex . It provides excellent thermal properties. Indeed, it is penetrable by water - so, if the customer is sweating, he or she will not sleep in direct contact with the body fluids (i.e., moisture-wicking ability). Moreover, this foam ensures that the sweat will ventilate out of the foam. And it also provides excellent breathability. Additionally, to ensure the perfect thermoregulation, the topper layer is infused with graphite – a good heat conductor – which ensures that the heat is dissipated as fast as possible. For more information on the Diamond degree Mattress, please check the following articles: Emma Diamond Medium Hybrid Emma Diamond Hard Emma Sleep Research Team Author: Filippo Calderaro

title: Snoring: What is it and how to treat it?
content: What is Snoring? Have you ever had someone complain to you about your snoring? Have you ever had the displeasure of being in the same room as someone whose sleep noises sound like a Boeing 747 taking off? We all have had our bad experiences with snoring. It is a problem that affects roughly 30% of the population – one which can be a real pain in the backside and can cause you waking up on the wrong side of the bad and having a terrible day. Snoring may occur nightly or intermittently. Males and those who are overweight are most likely to snore. However, it is an annoyance that affects people of both genders. It can cause major disruptions to your own sleep and your bed-partners’. It can cause un-refreshing broken sleep which translates into poor daytime function. Heart disease is believed to be casually linked to snoring due to the adverse effects sleep deprivation can have on one’s heart. Furthermore, about half of people who snore loudly have obstructive sleep apnea. As you sleep your throat becomes narrow and “floppy”. As you breathe, the walls of your throat begin to vibrate. These vibrations lead to the characteristic sound of snoring. The narrower your airway becomes, the greater the vibration and the louder the snoring. If the walls of your throat completely collapse – which sometimes happens – this can result in the cessation of breathing. This is called Sleep Apnea. It is a serious condition that requires medical attention. There are many factors which lead to excessive snoring. For example, the natural aging process leads to the relaxation of the throat muscles, resulting in snoring. Anatomical abnormalities of the nose and throat, such as enlarged tonsils or adenoids exaggerate narrowing of the throat during sleep and therefore can lead to snoring. Sleep positions, such as sleeping on your back, may lead to snoring. Also, alcohol is can act as a substantial muscle relaxant and its consumption in the evening can lead to excessive snoring. Consuming muscle relaxants in the evening will worsen snoring too. Symptoms of Snoring We all know what snoring sounds like. A vibrating, rattling and sometimes floor- shaking sound one makes while breathing during sleep. It may be a symptom of sleep apnea. You should consult your GP if you snore excessively and have one or more of the following: Excessive daytime sleepiness Morning headaches Recent weight gain Worsening levels of attention, concentration, or memory Observed pauses in breathing during sleep. Treatment For Snoring If you are told that you have excessive snoring, then you may want to consult your GP. They will perform a physical exam and will decide whether you need to consult a sleep expert who will then conduct a sleep test and determine if you have sleep apnea. You have a series of options when it comes to treating snoring: Lifestyle modification: i.e avoid the risk factors seen above like alcohol, sleep position training if possible, treatment of allergies, etc… Surgery: should be a last resort but surgery on the back of the throat and roof of the mouth, or the nose if applicable. Appliances: these include mainly oral appliances constructed by a dentist experienced in treatment of snoring and sleep apnea, but also appliances such as nasal dilators Lastly a CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure) appliance which blows room air into the back of the throat and preventing its collapse. CPAP is the method of choice when combating sleep apnea. If you are diagnosed with sleep apnea it is very important you treat it aggressively. Untreated sleep apnea will lead to daytime dysfunction and puts you at a higher risk of vascular disease. Coping With Snoring People who suffer from mild and/or occasional snoring, who wake up feeling refreshed, and function well during the day need not worry but may want to try some behavior modifications before consulting a doctor: Maybe lose some weight Avoid sleeping pills, antihistamines & tranquilizers before bedtime Avoid alcohol for at least four hours and heavy meals or snacks for three hours before you night night Establish regular sleeping patterns Sleep on your side. For most, snoring isn’t too big of a problem. However, if it persists and worsens you should consult your physician.

title: The Best Healthy Late Night Snacks
content: We have all been there. Lying in bed, stomach growling, and struggling to fall asleep. It’s too late to cook a full meal so all you need is a nice healthy snack to stop the rumbling in your tummy and help you fall asleep. These are our favorite late-night snacks to satisfy those midnight cravings. Cereal & Milk Let’s start off simple. Probably the most basic breakfast out there – cereal with milk – is the first nibble on our list. One study found that eating high-glycemic carbohydrates, which most corn-cereals are before you hit the lab reduced the time taken to fall asleep. So, for all you Insomniacs out there this may be the answer! Keep the serving sizes low, especially if you suffer from heartburn, as heavy meals can exacerbate the problem. The calcium in dairy plays a fundamental role in the production of the sleep hormone melatonin and acts as a natural relaxant for the body. Bowl of Berries Another simple snack. Berries are not only loaded with fiber, which fills you up, but they also contain magnesium, which relaxes the nerves and muscles in your body. It’s probably best to serve your berries Han Solo or add some chopped nuts or granola, or a drop of milk. PBJ Our neighbors across the pond call it peanut butter and jelly. Others call it to choke and slide, fluffernutter, and even gooey gobbler. The peanut butter and jam sandwich is a perfect nighttime snack to help you get to sleep faster. Peanut butter contains an amino acid called tryptophan. Tryptophan gets converted in the brain to melatonin, which promotes sleepiness. However, carbs like bread and jam are needed to make tryptophan more available to the brain. Therefore, it is the perfect combo for a pre-slumber snack. Also, if you’re feeling extra fitspo you can opt for whole-grain bread and sugar-free peanut butter. Cheese & Crackers If you are in the mood for something savory, a safe choice is cheese and crackers. Keep an eye on your portion sizes though as eating a lot of cheese can rack up your caloric intake. You may want to opt for whole-grain crackers, which contain filling fiber. You can try adding some grapes, apple slices, or whatever fruit you please. Fun fact: Cheese has also been shown to increase the amount of time you spend in REM sleep. So, if you want to have some vivid dreams stock up on the cheese! Fresh Veggies & Dip If you want something crunchy and low in calories, then this will do the job. Any combination of raw carrots, broccoli florets, cucumber slices, celery, pepper, and many more can help eradicate that growl in your stomach. If you want to enhance the flavor and get some calcium into you also, then use a dip made from low-fat cottage cheese, hummus, or Greek yogurt. Popcorn Most people’s favorite snack is also a great late-night nibble to satisfy to those midnight munchies. 3 cups of air-popped popcorn have less than 100 calories and around 4 grams of fiber to satisfy that hunger. Skip out on the butter if you don’t want that dad bod. Fresh Fruit & Nuts This easy-to-make snack is an ideal option if you’r tired from a busy day. Both fruit and nuts bring a lot of nutritional benefits to the table (if you pardon the pun) including vitamins, minerals, protein, complex carbs, healthy fats, and fiber. Maybe try: An apple with a handful of almonds A banana with a dozen pecans Or a pear with some walnuts. You can also try spreading peanut butter on banana slices (a favorite of mine) or dipping apple slices in almond butter. Porridge An Irish person’s favorite go-to breakfast can also act as a great late-night snack. It is a fantastic source of beta-glucan, which is a filling fiber that can help keep your cholesterol levels in check. Try using some instant porridge with fat-free milk, 1 tablespoon maple syrup, a sprinkle of cinnamon, and some dried fruit. It will have you snoozing in no time. Kiwis These little furry delicious fruits are both nutritious and figure-friendly. Two Kiwis contain only about 93 calories, 5 grams of fiber, and 190% of your Vitamin C RDI. Kiwis are also one of few fruits containing a substantial amount of serotonin, which is the nerve messenger that relaxes your body and helps you fall asleep better. It also helps you curb your carb cravings. Pistachios These delicious little nuts stand out among others of their kind for their high levels of the sleep-promoting hormone, melatonin. Few plant foods contain as much melatonin as pistachios. One ounce (28 grams) of shelled pistachios, has about 160 calories and about 6.5mg of melatonin. The amount of melatonin typically recommended aiding sleep is 0.5mg – 5mg. To Sum It All Up If you’re hungry or even just bored late at night – eating a snack that’s under 200 calories really shouldn’t tip the scales. Aim for minimally processed foods like your fruits, nuts, yogurt, and eggs to make your tasty late-night munch. Remember, the most important thing to keep in mind when making healthy snacks is to enjoy them, so feel free to experiment and see what works best for you.

title: Why am I so tired during the lockdown?
content: You might often have questions like, why am I so tired during the lockdown? What is wrong with me? Well, 2020 has been a somber year for most of us. Ok, who am I kidding? It’s been pretty terrible, and now many countries are facing a second lockdown right before the holiday season. As many go back to working 5 days a week from home and readjusting again to numerous hours spent at the same location, what have we learned thus far about proper sleep etiquette while in lockdown? Since the summer, there have been countless reports of people feeling more tired and groggy while working from home. Thanks to research and our sleep experts here at Emma, we have compiled a list of tips and habits to avoid that will ensure that you keep getting quality sleep even if your work routine is constantly changing. What makes you feel tired during this pandemic? Before heading right into the tips, let’s investigate what people are saying has changed in their lives since lockdown as it relates to sleep. All of these problems can be linked to “sleep inertia,” or when the body is still in a transitional state of being asleep and being awake. An increase in clumsiness – Maybe you are dropping all your pens or breaking plates on a more frequent basis. Perhaps you are making more mistakes in your work than you would have in the past. Or maybe you keep tripping on the same magenta carpet runner even though you’ve told yourself for years that you would replace it, but nevertheless, here it stays… Constantly distracted – This is a big one for me to be quite honest. I am one of those people who will be in the midst of writing an extraordinary article and then a bird flies by my window and suddenly I’m— “Where did it go? What kind of bird was that? I wish I was a bird…” Then I’ve lost fifteen minutes because of a pigeon. In a state of confusion – Are you finding it hard to remember things? Have you forgotten appointments that you would have never forgotten before? Sometimes even speaking with confidence and clarity is a chore. One time I called my boss by my boyfriend’s name, and well, it was awkward… All of these conditions can cause many problems for us when working from home while still having to meet deadlines and host virtual meetings. Sleep inertia can last anywhere from twenty minutes to an hour, and for some people, it can last several hours. This is why it is so important for us to take action to minimize our fatigue so that we wake up feeling refreshed and ready to be productive. How to fight against fatigue during the lockdown? Getting rid of fatigue is not as hard as you imagined, we summarised four easy-to-follow steps for you to get through this period. Step One: Go Outside Make sure you are going outside at least a few times a day when it is possible. The reason for this is that sunlight helps regulate our bodies. When it is light outside and we are exposed to the sun’s rays, our bodies naturally wake up and feel more alert. It also suppresses the release of melatonin which is the natural hormone that makes us feel sleepy. Likewise, when we are not exposed to sunlight as well as in the evening hours, the body starts to wind down and release melatonin. More often than not, people are spending way more time inside without going outside except for occasional trips to the supermarket and pharmacy. It would be wise to increase the frequency of going outside and combine it with some physical activity like jogging or just taking a walk around the neighborhood. Step Two: Don’t Break the Routine It can be really tempting to stay up until 2 am watching The X Factor or the latest Netflix show, but remember that you would not normally do that during the workweek so why are you doing it because you are working from home now? It is important for us to keep our schedules the same, so our bodies fall into the natural rhythm of feeling sleepy in the evenings and sleeping through the night. There is nothing worse than falling into that vampire mode of being wide awake at night and exhausted throughout the day. If you do find yourself unable to sleep during the night, get out of bed for a bit a do a simple task like washing dishes or reading to help ease your mind back into rest mode. Lastly, (and I know you’re going to hate it) don’t hit the snooze. Ok, maybe one time but if you had a bad night of sleep, it’s better to make it through the day tired than trying to get an extra hour or two, which throws off our sleep routine. If you need a mid-day nap, then take around 20 minutes to recharge but no longer. Step Three: Prepare Your Bedroom Have a bedroom ritual yet? If not, you can read our blog post about nighttime routines to get an in-depth understanding of how they can benefit your sleep. Basically, you want to optimize your bedroom for falling asleep. Make sure the temperature is exactly how you want it, preferably a little cool but not freezing. Have clean sheets on the bed and things put away in their correct stations. You don’t want to fall asleep in chaos but to an orderly, relaxing environment. If you like to fall asleep with white noise or quiet instrumental music, then go ahead and play our Sleepy Dreams playlist on Spotify . Have your windows closed and your shutters or blinds pulled so the sunlight does not wake you too early. All this preparation will help your body settle down when you finally hit the sheets and ease you into a relaxing slumber. Step Four: Do Something Relaxing Before Bed What can help you relax before sleeping? That might be yoga, reading, meditation, chatting with your close family or friends, or watching TV. Only you can know what will really calm you down and get you into your sleep state. We suggest that you start your relaxing activity at least an hour before you want to be asleep. Also, make sure that you aren’t relying upon alcohol or sleep tablets to make you feel sleepy. Alcohol has been proven to reduce quality sleep and leave you feeling worse in the morning. Tablets can also make you become dependent on chemicals to get to sleep, and over time your body will become somewhat immune to the dosage. If you are having serious problems with sleep deprivation, then please consult your physician to get a professional opinion. We hope you learned something from this blog post and that you can use it to make your life in lockdown a little easier. Remember that you aren’t alone out there and that millions of others are having to deal with these drastic changes. Make sure you give yourself a break from time to time and take care of yourself. Stay healthy and sleep tight!

title: Insomnia
content: Insomnia is the most common sleep disorder and refers to an inadequate ability to generate sleep, despite allowing oneself the adequate opportunity (!) to fall asleep. Meaning, patients provide enough time for rest (e.g. 7-9 hours at night) but cannot produce sufficient sleep quantity or quality. Insomnia can be divided into specific sub-types, although they are not mutually exclusive, which means they might occur together or separately: Onset Insomnia : Difficulty falling asleep Maintenance Insomnia : difficulty staying asleep To be diagnosed with insomnia it must occur at least three nights each week for more than three months (to separate insomnia from temporary sleep problems), lead to significant stress or daytime impairment , and stand independent from other mental disorders or medical conditions that could otherwise cause sleep disturbance (e.g. depression, Parkinson’s disease, diabetes). Prevalence rates of insomnia are estimated at 1 0-30% of adults ; however, rates are likely to be far more widespread with women affected twice as often as men. The two most common triggers of insomnia are emotional concerns or worry , and emotional distress or anxiety . On the biological level, emotional arousal leads to an overactive sympathetic nervous system, which controls the body’s fight-or-flight mechanism, resulting in increased heart rate, blood flow, metabolic rate, brain activity, and release of the stress-negotiating hormone cortisol. All of which makes it extremely difficult for our body to rest and fall asleep . Treatment The treatment for insomnia includes medication, psychotherapy, or behavioral therapy. On the one hand, they only promote sleepiness for a short time, thereby delaying the time needed to fall asleep, but distorting the natural sleep pattern (more sleep in N2, less REM sleep, and deep sleep). On the other hand, sleeping pills make people highly dependent on them while at the same time creating tolerance for the sleep-promoting effects, i.e. an ever-higher dose is necessary to achieve the same effects, and once patients stop taking the medication, they frequently suffer even more from insomnia than before, which is called rebound insomnia (the brain alters its balance of receptors as a reaction to the increased drug dose). In addition, those taking the medications often suffer from fatigue and reduced alertness the next day, whereby chronic use of sleeping pills even leads to a reduction in general life expectancy. For this reason, the use of sleeping pills should only be used infrequently and in a highly controlled manner!!! Another and more promising approach to counteract insomnia is cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) . Here, patients learn a set of techniques to improve sleep habits , address anxieties , for example. CBT-I allows for patient-focused treatment strategies and responses to individual needs.

title: Jetlag
content: What happens when we suffer from jetlag? Jetlag is a temporary disruption in circadian rhythm when travelling time zones. Our body works on an internal ~24-hour sleep-wake cycle (called circadian rhythm, cf. card on circadian rhythm) which is influenced by and can adapt to environmental cues , such as light. Review our Circadian Rhythm article here for more information. When travelling time zones , our circadian rhythm takes longer to adapt to the new time zone than the aeroplane on which we travelled. Consequently, our internal clock is somewhat desynchronised with the new environment . This may lead to daytime sleepiness , headaches , stomach problems or difficulties falling asleep . Jetlag is particularly hard to push when travelling eastward . This is since phase-shortening (east is ahead of time to west) is more difficult to adjust to than phase-lengthening (west is behind east). It is harder for us to fall asleep earlier as usual than staying up a bit longer when travelling westwards, especially since our circadian rhythm is innately a bit longer than 24 hours (~24 hours and 15 minutes), so eastward travelling contradicts our internal clock even stronger, whilst westward travelling approaches our internal clock. Rule of thumb : it takes one day per time zone crossed to adjust, i.e. travelling 2 time zones takes approximately 2 days to adjust. Exposing yourself to sunlight supports re-synchronising your circadian rhythm faster and fighting jetlag!

title: Narcolepsy
content: Narcolepsy is a chronic neurological disorder that severely disrupts the body’s sleeping and waking cycles. It is characterized by extreme daytime drowsiness and is caused by abnormalities in the central nervous system and emerges in most cases in childhood to young adulthood. It affects the systems in the brain that help us stay awake, such as the brain stem and hypothalamus. The most prominent symptoms of this condition are sleep attacks (in which the desire to fall asleep is overwhelming), cataplexy (sudden bouts of muscle weakness), and sleep paralysis (a temporary inability to move while falling asleep or waking up). Frequent Symptoms Excessive Daytime Sleepiness (EDS) The hallmark of the condition (everyone with narcolepsy has it), EDS causes people to become extremely drowsy during the day, leading to sleep attacks. It arises regardless of how much sleep a person gets. These are short periods in which the desire to sleep comes on quickly and is insatiable. In between sleep attacks, narcoleptic people feel rested and alert. Cataplexy A significant portion of narcolepsy cases also entails cataplexy. This sudden bout of muscle weakness, absence of muscle tone, and loss of voluntary motion often arise when a narcoleptic person experiences strong emotional responses, as in laughter, pangs of fear or stress, or sudden excitement. The severity of this condition ranges, with some experiencing only a few of these attacks in a lifetime, while others have multiple episodes a day. Sleep Paralysis Arising when narcoleptic people are close to falling asleep or just waking up, sleep paralysis is a temporary inability to perform voluntary movements or speak. A condition that lasts anywhere from a few seconds to several minutes, it resembles cataplexy and the state of the body when people are in the dream state of sleep (called REM). As with these conditions, the debilitation isn’t permanent and doesn’t have lingering effects; people quickly regain the ability to speak and move as expected. Hallucinations Vivid hallucinations often accompany sleep paralysis and may arise when a narcoleptic person is falling asleep (hypnagogic hallucinations) or shortly after waking up (hypnopompic hallucinations). These are most often visual in nature—though other senses can also be affected—and they may take on a frightening or jarring character. While the symptoms themselves aren’t lethal, they’re certainly disruptive, and they can cause car accidents, falls, or other issues. If you or someone is experiencing EDS or other symptoms—the recommendation is to always seek professional help and the best would be a Sleep Expert doctor. Treatments Currently, there is no cure for narcolepsy, but medications and behavioural treatments can improve/help to cope with symptoms. There is a drug commonly prescribed to help with daytime sleep attacks. But also antidepressants are often used to fight cataplexy and sleep paralysis, which again do not eliminate the symptoms completely and come with their own downsides. Behavioural treatments are also a good option, which includes taking short naps during the day, practising good sleep habits (e.g. avoiding caffeinated drinks late in the day, consistent bedtime routines), flexible arrangement of social / work-related engagements

title: Sleep Apnea
content: What is sleep apnea? Sleep apnea is a disorder that involves the complete or the temporary stopping of breathing at intervals of at least 10 seconds during sleep. This leads to a decrease in oxygen content in the blood and sleep fragmentation . It usually affects men aged between 40 and 70 years old. It also commonly occurs in elderly individuals and those suffering from obesity. In general, this sleep disorder can be divided into three categories: Obstructive apnea: This involves real airway obstruction. Central apnea: In this case, the malfunctioning of the respiratory activity is due to a temporary loss of the nervous stimulus on the way to the respiratory muscles. Mixed apnea: This last type is simply a mix of the two previous types of apnea. Symptoms and effects of sleep apnea Usually, the most common symptom of sleep apnea is snoring . In fact, due to the dysfunction of the breath, this becomes stronger. For example, prolonged breathing pauses, groans, and puffs are observed in sleepers who suffer from sleep apnea. The causes of sleep apnea can vary, but aggravating factors include the use of sedatives, hypothyroidism, nasal obstruction, or the supine position during sleep. The effects of this disorder may include difficulty falling asleep at night , excessive tiredness during the day , frequent headaches, and concentration problems . Moreover, it has also been identified as a risk factor for other clinical consequences such as systematic hypertension, cardiovascular disease, stroke. Studies have also shown that men suffering from sleep apnea have significantly lower levels of the hormone testosterone than those of a matching comparison sample not suffering from sleep apnea. Risk factors associated with sleep apnea that might increase vulnerability for the disorder. The risk factors are advancing age, male sex, obesity, family history, menopause, craniofacial abnormalities, heavy cigarette smoking, and alcohol use. Medical treatment and advice Although sleep apnea is recognized as a serious disease, it often stays undetected. Here, sleeping partners or familiars can help to report any abnormalities during the night (e.g. heavy snoring, breathing problems/pauses during sleep). Early recognition helps appropriate and effective therapy , counteracting serious health consequences. Treatment of milder forms of sleep apnea includes weight reduction, quitting smoking, maintenance of a regular sleep pattern, or treatment of nasal allergies to support better breathing at night. If symptoms do not improve or in case of severe sleep apnea, various treatments/devices are possible: the most common and reliable method is CPAP (Continuous positive airway pressure), a machine you put on before going to bed which delivers air pressure through a mask to keep the upper airway passages open. Others are oral appliances designed to keep your throat open, or supplemental oxygen machines to counteract a shortage of oxygen during sleep. But these are only a few examples of a range of possible treatment methods. Fun-fact Snoring is a problem that makes no economic distinction. Indeed, did you know that Tom Cruise uses to sleep in a soundproof "snoratorium" because his night sleep is characterized by loud snoring? Did you know that sleep apnea can be related to sexsomnia. It is a relatively uncommon parasomnia mainly affecting males. Sexsomnia happens during non-REM sleep and is not linked to dreaming. Although aberrant sexual activity during sleep was initially reported in 1989, the term ‘sexsomnia’ wasn’t created until 2003 when 11 individuals displaying sexual activities during sleep were recorded. Treatments that enhance the quality of sleep may help decrease the occurrence of incidents

title: Sleep Paralysis
content: Sleep Paralysis As explained in our Sleep Cycles article , during REM sleep our skeletal muscles are completely paralyzed: no tone in the voluntary muscles of the body (involuntary muscles which control automatic operations like breathing continue to operate!) Normally, when we wake up and return to consciousness, the brain releases the body from paralysis immediately. In the case of narcolepsy ( a sleeping disorder ), it may occur that paralysis prolongs into the state of being awake. This leads to an inability to move your body – not even eyelids or mouth. Within some minutes, the paralysis should cease, and f ull-body control should be regained. Paralysis, however, is not unique to narcolepsy but can also occur among healthy individuals. Generally, paralysis does not pose any worrying risks, however, if it occurs regularly or is getting worse, you should see your doctor. It has not yet been fully understood why paralysis develops but it has been linked to other (sleeping) disorders or irregularities, e.g.: insomnia, disrupted sleeping patterns due to shift work or jetlag, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety disorders, panic disorder. A regular sleep rhythm, measures that promote a good night's sleep in general, and adherence to sufficient sleep duration help to prevent paralysis. Review our Sleep The Sleep Architecture: Sleep Stages & Sleep cycles article Get more info about the Sleep disorder Narcolepsy

title: Social Jetlag
content: What is social jetlag? The term jetlag is normally associated with long-distance flights where it refers to a temporary disruption in circadian rhythm when travelling time zones. The circadian rhythm is the body’s internal sleep-wake cycle which repeats roughly every 24 hours and is hence called circadian (from Latin “circa diem”, for “approximately one day” Review our Jetlag article here & the Circadian Rhythm article here. But for a disturbance in the circadian rhythm, you do not necessarily need an aeroplane! Our social or professional everyday life can also throw us out of phase. How? This question is actually easy to answer: Our day has 24 hours - but quite often, our schedule calls for many more To do justice to all tasks or events, we start cutting back on time at one particular juncture: our sleep. "I don't need that much sleep!" or "I'll catch up on my sleep at the weekend!" While our body actually wants to shut down and needs sleep to recover , our social circumstances do not allow us to meet this need and we postpone and most likely shorten our sleep time. Our social clock is entering into competition with our biological clock, so to speak. What are the consequences of social jet lag? Social jetlag, like travel-related jetlag, can lead to daytime sleepiness, headaches, stomach problems or difficulties falling asleep. It is usually more frequent and longer-lasting than our holiday trips by plane, a serious burden of sleep debt can accumulate. This has damaging cumulative effects - both short and long-term - that result in wide-ranging and dire consequences on our health, such as: a weakened immune system, a rise in the risk of many diseases including cancer, hypertension, coronary diseases, stroke, obesity and diabetes But also, psychological distress and disorders can be associated with sleep deprivation due to social jet lag, for example: Listlessness, anxiety, and depression A note to all “weekend dormice” among us: sleep debt cannot simply be made up with a few extra hours Studies have demonstrated that individuals who cut their sleep down to five hours during the week but make up for it on the weekend with extra sleep, still pay a cost! What promotes social jetlag? Besides a busy schedule, social media in particular have emerged as a risk factor. The reason for this is that many of us like to exchange some news, watch the latest holiday pictures of our friends or funny videos in the evening before going to bed. This, however, increases the likelihood of losing sleep, because: The exchange of exciting news will make us more awake again Once in hand, we often find it difficult to put the phone away and spend we spend a lot of valuable time being hijacked from sleep Exposure to artificial lighting emitted by the screens of the TV, tablets, computers, mobiles etc., can adversely impact sleeping behaviour and sleep continuity by inhibiting melatonin, a sleep-inducing hormone Especially among teenagers the evening hours are popular, to socialise or relax and they prefer to go to bed later. To still have enough restorative sleep they needed to sleep in later in the morning than younger children. However, as our schooling system usually does not allow time for late mornings, this can also lead to social jetlag. A fact that is reflected in impaired mental and cognitive performances among many pupils and students. Hence, many sleep scientists urge that all this is to be taken into account when it comes to the management and structure of everyday school life.

title: Circadian Rhythm
content: Table of Content Intro What is a circadian rhythm? Why do we need a circadian rhythm? How does the circadian rhythm (in humans) work on a neurobiological level? What happens when our circadian rhythm is out of tact? What factors can influence our circadian rhythm? What are chronotypes and how are they related to circadian rhythms? Intro The circadian rhythm , also known as our Inner clock , does not only manage when we sleep but actually all regular behavior, as eating for example. The inner clock is determined by different factors as gym, hormones, temperature, and our behavior. However, the most important and influencing factor comes from light. Through our eyes, Our brain is constantly receiving signals by receptors sensitive of blue eye - setting out our internal clock Besides, other processes, substances created also raise the need of sleep. What is a circadian rhythm? Let’s start at the very basic: The term circadian comes from Latin and is composed of the terms circa (approximately) and Diem (day) In chronobiology, circadian rhythms are defined as processes with a period length of about 24 hours, hence the circa + Diem. These cycles are determined internally , we speak of an endogenous rhythm or an internal clock - in contrast to processes that are generated by external factors and therefore exogenous. The ~24-h rhythm repeats itself continuously unless we influence it by external forces - but more about that in a minute. Probably the best-known circadian rhythm is the sleep-wake rhythm , which causes us to switch repeatedly between sleep and wakefulness - yesterday, today, and tomorrow. However, other physiological parameters also exhibit a rhythm with a ~24-hour period, e.g. our body temperature or the secretion of certain hormones fluctuate in a 24-hour rhythm. Why do we need a circadian rhythm? With the rotation of the earth, there are periodically recurring changes such as changes from brightness to darkness, warmer and colder temperatures, but also aspects such as availability of food or lurking threats. Living organisms that adapt to such changes can optimize their ability to function and thus ensure their chances of survival. This is why circadian rhythms are not only found in humans, but also in animals and plants (activation of photosynthesis). The essential function of the circadian rhythm is to classify life processes in terms of time. For example, the activation and deactivation of individual processes in the body enable us to sleep and regenerate at night but to be fully functional, alert, and active during the day. How does the circadian rhythm (in humans) work on a neurobiological level? Circadian rhythms throughout the body are linked to a central circuit, sometimes called the circadian pacemaker . This pacemaker is located in the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) - part of the hypothalamus - just behind the root of your nose. The SCN is very sensitive to light, which is why light exposure is closely linked to the circadian rhythm. The SCN is very sensitive to light, which is why light exposure is closely linked to the circadian rhythm. In darkness, the SCN sends a corresponding signal to the pineal gland, which in turn produces, among others, the sleep-inducing hormone melatonin. What happens when our circadian rhythm is out of tact? If the circadian rhythm is disturbed, it has major influences on our ability to function properly. Our hormone production would go haywire, blood pressure, body temperature or heart rate, etc, would no longer follow the sequence to which we have adapted over the years. Not only can this pose serious health risks, but it would also significantly reduce our well-being and productivity. If our internal clock no longer signals "night" to our body, it stays on high alert. Consequently, we have difficulty falling asleep and repeatedly wake up during the night or early in the morning. This is accompanied by sleep fragmentation, lower sleep efficiency, and also poorer quality sleep. What factors can influence our circadian rhythm? Light is the main synchronizer, also called key Zeitgeber, of our internal circadian clock: Light affects the production of melatonin, the sleep-inducing hormone that signals night to the body. Melatonin production slowly increases at the onset of darkness and stays elevated for the course of an approximately twelve-hour period. Although melatonin does not participate in the generation of sleep itself, it increases the sleep pressure we feel (i.e. tiredness and need to sleep), and thus times when sleep is going to occur. During the day, however, melatonin levels should be low as we do not want to feel tired. The suppression of melatonin by natural/artificial light is hence intended and called for during the day as it promotes attention, alertness, and mood. For more information on the impact of light cf. our card on “Light & Circadian Rhythm” > “Artificial Light” / “Blue Light” / “Light Therapy” Our social activities can have an impact, too: Breakfast/dinner times, social events and parties in the evening, etc. can have an impact on our daily rhythm as they give a temporal structure to our everyday life. The relationship between the circadian rhythm and food intake is also used for nutrition tips: this is referred to as the principle of chrononutrition or time-restricted-eating (TRE) It is a form of intermittent fasting in which daily food intake is adapted to the circadian rhythm and limited to a period of 4-12 hours It does not require calorie restriction, but a consistent daily eating window A systematic meta-analysis of 19 studies from 2020 (Moon et al.) found positive effects of TRE on our bodies, including weight loss, reduction in fat mass whilst maintaining fat-free mass, blood pressure and cholesterol profile Depending on its intensity, we even speak of social jetlag Check more information about J Jetlag - A factor all too familiar to globetrotters and business travelers: When traveling time zones, our circadian rhythm takes longer to adapt to the new time zone than the airplane on which we traveled. Consequently, our internal clock is somewhat desynchronized with the new environment. This may lead to daytime sleepiness, headaches, stomach problems, or difficulties falling asleep. Jetlag is particularly hard to push when traveling eastward. Check more information about Jetleg here What are chronotypes and how are they related to circadian rhythms? While all of us have circadian rhythms, this does not mean that they are all in sync between individuals. While some people may sleep earlier, or reach the lowest point of body temperature earlier in the evening, others may find sleep only later in the night, etc. These inter-individual differences in the circadian rhythms are expressed in different chronotypes . Generally speaking, a distinction is made between the morning type (also known as the lark) and the evening type (known as the owl). Morning types wake up earlier and reach their cognitive and energetic peak already early in the day. In return, they also become tired in the evening more quickly and reach their lowest core body temperature earlier in the night than evening types, for example. Evening types take longer to wake up in the morning - this may be due to a later onset of cortisol secretion - but are still wide awake when others are already fast asleep. But of course, the story is not quite as black and white! There are many subcategories and by now a number of questionnaires or tests are available to determine one's own personal chronotype. Fun-Facts Research shows that people go to bed later in the days leading up to a full moon and are sleepless, although the reasons are unclear. What makes this discovery even more interesting is that the effect of the full moon is exerted both on populations living in urban contexts, suburban contexts, and rural contexts (having, therefore, different exposure to sunlight and moonlight). You can find an interactive version of these findings at the following link .

title: How much Sleep do I need?
content: There is no "one size fits it all" answer to the question of how many hours of sleep we need, as the amount of sleep you need depends on a variety of factors such as age, health, lifestyle, etc. But according to the National Sleep Foundation , the general recommendation is: 14-17 hours for new-borns 12-15 hours for infants 11-14 hours for toddlers 10-13 hours for pre-schoolers 9-11 hours for school-aged children 8-10 for teenagers 7-9 hours for young adults and adults 7-8 hours for older adults Curiosity about teenagers sleep habits : Teenagers may find evening hours especially attractive to socialize or relax and prefer to go to bed later. To still have their amount of sleep needed to feel refreshed they are hence also likely to sleep later in the morning than younger children. This also corresponds to the fact that our internal clocks (circadian rhythm) shift during puberty. Check out the Circadian Rhythm article here Sleep Scientists urge that all this be taken into account when it comes to everyday school life, as many teenagers were regularly deprived of important hours of sleep in the morning and consequently showed impaired mental performance. "Am I getting enough sleep?" If you are wondering whether you are getting enough sleep, here are three questions that might help you: Do you have trouble getting up in the morning? / Would you have slept past your alarm clock? Do you have trouble focusing during the day? / Can you function optimally without caffeine? Do you regularly doze off during the day? Deep Sleep Deep sleep, also called slow-wave sleep because of its characteristic brain waves, is crucial to feeling refreshed the next morning. Deep sleep is considered to be the most restorative sleep phase and is associated with vital functions, among such: production of growth hormones, strengthening of the immune system, repair and regrow of body tissues, and memory consolidation. Deep sleep occurs in longer periods during the first third of the night with adults spending about 10-20% of total sleep time in deep sleep. However, the assumption that deep sleep alone determines how long we should sleep is wrong ! Alongside deep sleep, the remaining sleep stages also bear significant functions . Check out our article of Sleep Stages here What happens when you are sleep-deprived ? Not getting enough sleep leads to sleep debt , which is essentially the difference between the amount of sleep we get and the amount we need . Studies have shown that people who sleep five hours or less on weekdays, but extra long on weekends, still pay a significant cost. Among them, for example, is an increased weight gain due to: excessive caloric intake in the evening (the longer we stay awake, the more hormones are released that boost our hunger and appetite), reduced energy expenditure, and changes in the body's use of insulin; impaired cognitive and physical performance; increased sensitivity and irritability; and many more. A study conducted by the AAA Foundation in Washington, DC, in 2016 quantified a driver’s relative risk of being involved in a car crash relative to their sleep deprivation. They found that drowsy driving leads to significantly higher crash rates: up to 11.5 times the crash rate when sleeping less than 4 hours compared to drivers who had slept for at least 7 hours. Therefore, it is crucial to get the recommended daily amount of sleep and practice sleep hygiene regularly – for your own good and for your fellow men! Deep sleep is considered to be the most restorative sleep phase and is associated with vital functions, among such: production of growth hor What happens when you oversleep ? While we know that too little sleep can lead to serious and significant impairments, we cannot deduce a linear relationship between sleep and health/performance, according to the idea of “more is more”. Rather, there seems to be an inverted U-shaped relationship: Neither too little nor too much sleep is advisable – but the golden mean. Just like over-eating, over-drinking, over-breathing is detrimental to our health, over-sleeping is most likely to come with drawbacks too! It is best to remember that too much of anything can be bad. From an evolutionary perspective , sleeping at night is considered adaptive to protect us from accidents or predators in the dark and to preserve energy reserves. During the day, however, our bodies are equipped to be active, to forage, and reproduce. An extended period of sleep would here be maladaptive! Oversleeping is often associated with physical or mental disorders , such as sleep apnea, depression, or side effects of medications. Effects that may be linked to over-sleeping include diabetes, obesity, back pain, depression, heart disease, for example. Fun Fact Tigers rest for 16 hours a day. A giraffe, on the other hand, only needs two hours of sleep a day. And a snake can even sleep for up to three years! Did you already know?

title: Light & Circadian Rhythm
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS Why does light matter in general? What happens when we are exposed to light? Blue Light Artificial Light Why does light matter in general? As per our Circadian Rhythm article, Light is the main synchronizer , also called key Zeitgeber, of our internal circadian clock which defines our ~24h sleep-wake cycle. Light affects the production of melatonin , a sleep-inducing hormone that signals night to the body. Melatonin production slowly increases at the onset of darkness and stays elevated for the course of an approximately twelve-hour period. By this, melatonin helps maintain the body’s internal sleep-wake cycle which repeats roughly every 24 hours and is hence called a circadian rhythm (from Latin “circa diem”, for “approximately one day”, cf. card on Sleep Cycle or Circadian Rhythm). Although melatonin does not participate in the generation of sleep itself , it increases the sleep pressure we feel (i.e. tiredness and need to sleep), and thus times when sleep is going to occur. During the day , however, melatonin levels should be low as we do not want to feel tired. The suppression of melatonin by natural/artificial light is hence intended and called for during the day as it promotes attention , alertness , and mood . (Illustration showing levels of cortisol (stress hormone which makes us stay awake during the day), in blue connected with bluish light emitted by the full moon shown on the left window, and levels of melatonin (relax hormone which makes us sleep at night) in red connected with reddish light emitted by the half-moon shown on the right window. Source: Sleep Science by Emma - The Sleep Company) What happens when we are exposed to light? The exposure of light induces phase shifts of our clock resulting in either direction: a delaying: biological rhythm shifts to a later clock time with light exposure in the evening, or advancing: biological rhythm shifts to an earlier clock time with light exposure in the morning. The use of light therapy to treat circadian rhythm sleep disorders has proven to be a potentially effective treatment . In one study, the authors examined whether 30 min blue-light pulses are effective in shifting sleep with preservation of sleep integrity and performance in a home-setting light therapy study. The authors found that: blue-light therapy was able to support a sleep phase by increasing a shift in the melatonin rhythm and improving sleep timing. In another study, scientists used a sleep mask to provide a train of light pulses of 2-second duration every 30 seconds through closed eyelids. They found that: blue light pulses given early in the sleep episode impacted the melatonin secretion and significantly delayed circadian phases in older adults thereby, adjusting circadian phase in a home setting. Recommendations by the experts at Emma: If we use ligh correctly, it can positively enrich our sleep as well as our performance and well-being during the day. We recommend starting the day with as much sunlight as possible and avoiding blue light in the evening. This may help to get (back) in sync with your own circadian rhythm. Blue Light Exposure to blue light, emitted by the screens of TV, tablets, computer, mobiles etc., can adversely impact sleeping behaviour and sleep continuity by inhibiting melatonin, a sleep-inducing hormone. A study conducted at Harvard University revealed that blue light suppresses the production of melatonin for twice as long as does green light. Hence, although the exposure of blue light during the day will help us to stay alert by suppressing melatonin, exposure in the evening / at night can be detrimental to sleep quality. Cajochen et al., also showed that evening expsoure to blue light lead to suppression of melatonin release more than green light, thereby, offsetting the carcidian rhythm (our internal sleep-wake pattern of approx. 24h, cf. card on Circadian Rhythm) and reducing sleepiness. Blue light exposure also elevated the core body temperature (however, a drop in core body temperature helps us to fall asleep and maintain sleep) and heart rate (which also lowers when we calm down and fall asleep). A study showed that participants who read an e-book before bedtime took an average of nearly 10 min longer to fall asleep compared to individuals who read a printed book. Reading an e-book before bedtime also led to: reduced melatonin release, decreased sleepiness before bedtime, significantly less REM sleep (stage of sleep where most dreaming occurs, cf. card on REM Sleep), and increased levels of morning grogginess. Recommendations by the experts at Emma We recommend keeping the bedroom free from electronic devices such as Iphones and tablets. If their use is absolutely essential before bedtime, then filter apps that block blue-light should be installed and used to reduce exposure to artificial light as much as possible. Artificial Light What effect does artificial light have? Exposure to artificial light emitted by recent technologies, such as LEDs, computer screens, mobile phones or televisions suppresses melatonin production, delaying its release in the body. This creates a phase delay, which means that the peak of melatonin occurs later than the time it would otherwise, leading to restless sleep and late sleep timings. Exposure to artificial lighting can hence delay the circadian clock resulting in late sleep timing and social jetlag (a discrepancy between biological and social timing), which may ultimately lead to detrimental effects on health, such as depression, cancer, cardiovascular diseases. Persons, shift workers, for example, who are regularly exposed to unusual light-dark cycles, are therefore exposed to sleep disturbances and serious health risks. What effect does natural light have? In contrast, natural light induces the synthesis of melatonin. Exposure to natural light aligns the circadian rhythm to the natural light-dark cycle of the environment, resulting in improved sleep patterns and earlier bedtimes. Human bodies can adjust the production of melatonin according to changes in the light-dark cycle of the environment: the circadian clock adapts to the seasonal variations, naturally shortening (sleeping shorter) during the short summer nights and lengthening (sleeping longer) to align with the long winter nights. A camping weekend in natural light can reset the circadian timing and help alleviate social jetlag that contributes to Monday morning grogginess. Recommendations by the experts at Emma We recommend reducing exposure to artificial light at night since it can offset the body's biological clock and suppress the production of the sleep-induing hormone, melatonin. Additionally, to help the body's internal clock reset we recommend expsoure to natural light in the nature: Take out your camping gear and venture into the wilderness for a weekend!

title: Sleep Deprivation: Sleep Loss & Sleep Debt
content: What happens when you are sleep-deprived? Not getting enough sleep leads to sleep debt , which is the difference between the amount of sleep we get and the amount we need. Consequences Find below some consequences of it: Sleep and obesity Lack of sleep alters levels of hormones that affect appetite and cause metabolic changes that can increase the predisposition to obesity. In fact, individuals who sleep less than 7 hours per night are more likely to have higher average body mass indexes and to develop obesity than those who slept for more than 7 hours. Sleep-Immune crosstalk Lack of sleep will suppress the immune system. In fact, people who sleep six hours or less a night are four times more likely to catch a cold when exposed to the virus, compared to those who sleep more than seven hours a night. Sleep to ward off diseases Inadequate sleep can raise the risk of many diseases including cancer, hypertension, coronary diseases, stroke, depression, and diabetes. Sleep and accidents Drowsy driving has been associated with a shortened lifespan due to high risk of car crashes. Sleeping six hours per night can increase your risk of having a car crash by 33% compared to sleeping seven or eight hours a night. Sleep and memory Without getting the adequate amount of sleep, it is much harder for our brain to absorb, process, and recall new information. Sleep deficits further lead to impaired judgments and poor vigilance and concentration. Sleep and mood Sleep deprivation may lead to irritability, impatience, and moodiness. Sleep abnormalities co-occur with various mental disorders, such as anxiety disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, depression or bipolar disorder. Causes Personal choice Some people don’t realize that the body needs adequate sleep, and prefer staying up late. Illness Illness such as colds and tonsillitis can cause snoring, gagging and frequent waking and effect directly on sleep Sleep disorder This includes sleep apnea, snoring and periodic limb movement disorder can disturb a person´s sleep. Work Jobs that have shifts or frequent travels can disrupt the sleep-wake cycles on a regular basis. Airline crew tends to have erratic sleeping patterns Poor sleep hygiene Drinking coffee or smoking cigarettes close to bedtime habit can stimulate the nervous system and makes you sleepless. The sleeping environment sleeping in an environment such as a room that is too hot or cold, noisy neighbors, and a snoring partner can disrupt your sleep. Medications To treat epilepsy or ADHD, the drugs that are used can cause insomnia. Babies Parents mostly experience sleep deprivation because their babies are frequently waking up in the night for feeding or comfort. Sleep Problems and Disorders Sleep problems or sleep disorders refer to conditions that affect sleep quality, timing, or duration. Sleep problems can be triggered by numerous factors, including psychological (e.g. stress, anxiety, loneliness, high-performance pressure), physiological (e.g. problems breathing or other illnesses), and environmental (e.g. aging, jet lag, ambient temperature, diet). Check our Sleep Problems and Disorders informative folder for more information here . Please note: the knowledge discussed is meant to be informative, and shouldn't take the place of advice from a health care provider. If you or someone shares suffering from a sleep disorder or other medical condition, please see or recommend seeking for a professional. and learn about the good habits you can add to your routine to get a good night's sleep by checking our Sleep Hygiene article .

title: Sleep Hygiene: how to build good sleep habits
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS What is sleep hygiene? How to build better sleeping habits? Watch: video with tips to keep a good sleep hygiene Tips for getting a good night's sleep Rules for improving your sleep What is sleep hygiene? Sleep hygiene is a set of habits you develop to get a good night's sleep on a day-to-day basis. It refers to a set of behavioral and environmental recommendations to help you to achieve your best during the night and Awaken your Best during the day. These recommendations relate to different areas of life and are usually quite straightforward so that they may be tailored to suit individual needs and preferences. How to build better sleeping habits? Build an environment that promotes sleep hygiene . E.g. Block electronic devices from your bedroom or have dimmable light. Set routines so the behavior/sleep hygiene measurements feel automatic within the time. Habits can solidify through repetition until we perform them almost automatically, so you don't have to force yourself every day whether you should stick to them. Set a fixed bedtime, turn off your mobile phone 2 hours before going to bed every evening. Make the new routines enjoyable . E.g. spoil yourself with a special bath for your warm bathing in the evening. The experience of enjoyable moments prompts your brain to release dopamine, a hormone involved in the regulation of emotion, motivation, and movement, which strengthens the habit even more. Train your habits as a muscle. Some adjustments may take a great deal of willpower and self-control . But the good news is will power can be strengthened over time. Find your perfect formula. Ideal sleep hygiene varies among individuals , we should test out various adjustments to find out what suits us best. Do not put yourself too much pressure . (Especially when it comes to calming down or falling asleep!) and do not try to implement each recommendation at once! This could most likely lead to unrealistic expectations, disappointment, and discouragement. Small steps are a good start , and you can go from there! Watch: video with tips to keep a good sleep hygiene Tips for getting a good night's sleep Stick to a Sleep schedule Exercise at least ~30 min/day but not later than 2-3 hours before bedtime Avoid caffeine (coffee, cola, black/green tea, chocolate) and nicotine Avoid alcoholic drinks before bed Avoid large or heavy meals and drinks late in the evening Avoid (if possible) medicines that delay or disrupt your natural sleep pattern Do not take naps after 3pm Give yourself time to relax and calm down before going to bed (not by watching TV!) Take a hot bath, cuddle with your beloved or make yourself comfortable in a fluffy, warm blanket before bed Keep your bedroom dark, col and free from any phones, tablets, laptops, TVs, and the like Have the right sunlight exposure in the morning Do not lie in bed awake Last but not least: Invest in a comfortable, high-quality mattress, pillow, and bed linen!! Rules for improving your sleep

title: The Sleep Architecture: Sleep Stages & Sleep cycles
content: Table of Contents How is our sleep structured? What happens at each stage of sleep? N1 N2 Sleep Spindles K Complexes N3 REM How is our sleep structured? The way sleep is structured is referred to as Sleep Architecture . Sleep is composed of a series of so-called sleep cycles . A sleep cycle is composed of 4 sleep stages , which are divided into non-REM (N1, N2, N3) and REM sleep (REM = Rapid Eye Movement) These 4 stages make up one sleep cycle, which takes around 90 minutes to complete. Each stage of sleep has its own unique purpose fulfilling a distinct physiological and psychological function and they occur in the same sequence. Adults need 5 sleep cycles per night, which takes up to 7- 8 hours. Curious about How much sleep do we need at what age? Check out our article for more info here . What happens at each stage of sleep? N1 The phase that transitions from wakefulness to sleep. Begins within minutes of lying down, but can take longer depending on sleep habits, disturbances, sleep disorders, and each person's physiology. The duration can vary between 1 - 7 minutes. Physiological changes Eyes close Muscles relax Core body temperature decreases Your pineal gland begins to release the sleep-inducing hormone: melatonin Your brain waves shift from alpha waves of relaxation to theta waves of sleep You may start dreaming during this stage Curiosity facts: Some people may lose their sense of time and place during this phase. We may not even know we are still asleep. Quite easy to be disturbed during this stage. Hypnic jerks: sudden contractions of the muscle that can wake us up (sense of falling or ripping) - considered normal though they can be worsened by caffeine, stress, or some medications. The difficulty of entering the n1 stage is a common symptom of Insomnia. N2 Half of the four cycles of sleep are spent in this stage. The body starts preparing for deep sleep. Though the stage is similar to the n1 stage, there are some key changes that occur: Physiological changes Eye movement stops Reduced awareness of the environment Lower heart rate and body temperature Your muscles will tense and relax Your upper airway muscles relax Sleep spindles start K complexes Sleep Spindles Are 1 to 2 seconds of bursts of activity, results from interactions between the thalamic and cortical neurons: Neurons from the thalamus (center of the brain) & Neurons from the cortex (top of the brain) start to interact with one another to create these spindles: The Sleep Spindles are essential for forming memories , remembering dreams , and helping transfer short-term to long-term memories . K Complexes are brain waves generated in the cortex that last more than half-second, can be seen on an EGG (electroencephalogram). K complexes help us process information, meaning memory consolidation. Help also to synchronize the sleep stages. They're believed to help us sleep by preventing us from waking up to non-threatening external stimuli, however too much time in this phase isn't a good thing. It can indicate a sleep disorder like sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome, or insomnia. Sleep spindle and K-complex waves comparison in an EGG (electroencephalogram): N3 Essential phase to body recovery and is the most restorative of the sleep stages. Help with the growth and repair of bones, muscles, and tissues. It is essential for the immune system. It starts usually 40 minutes after sleep. Physiological changes Your body releases hormones that help with appetite control Blood flow to the brain decreases While blood flow to your muscles increases which gives them oxygen and restorative nutrients Your blood pressure and heart rate decreases even further Memories continue to be consolidating Breathing becomes slower Sleep spindle activity decreases It is the last non-rem stage and is commonly referred to as Slow Wave Sleep . This is a deep stage of sleep and it's difficult to be woken up during this time. If you woke up during this stage you may feel groggy and the mental performance will be slower for about 30 minutes due to the reduced cerebral blood flow during this stage. REM Last stage of the sleep cycle During REM, the pons turns off signals to neurons in the spine, preventing us from acting out our vivid dreams. Emotion processing and consolidation heal emotional wounds problem-solving skills creativity Physiological changes Paralysis of the muscles Rapid and random eye movements Fluctuation in breathing Circulation and body temperature unique to REM sleep Vivid dreams Mind is active Brain waves are similar to those when awake Failure to achieve REM sleep can lead to: Fatigue and cognitive impairment Reduced immunity Impaired hormone production Changes in metabolism High risk of neurological disorders like dementia An inefficient sleep cycle can actually lead to the same consequences of sleep deprivation including: Reduced concentration or hand-eye coordination Daytime sleepiness Irritability Sleep should always be sufficient and efficient . Get more information about Sleep deprivation consequences and common causes here . Sleep problems and sleep disorders here . and learn about the good habits you can add to your routine to get a good night's sleep checking our Sleep Hygiene article .

title: The True Importance of Sleep
content: Everybody does it. It’s perfectly natural. Some do it naked and some do it with their clothes on. Some do it in a bed, and some do it wherever it pleases them. Yes, that’s right we’re talking about sleep. What is sleep? Sleep is one of the fundamental pillars of a happy and healthy life, along with nutrition and exercise. It is the key to maintaining a healthy mind, body, and soul. Below are some of sleep’s great benefits and some reasons why you shouldn’t skip out on it. What are sleep’s effects on the immune system? Missing out on sleep can have some serious adverse effects on your immune system. Without enough sleep, your body produces fewer cytokines. These are types of proteins that prevent infection and inflammation. They are produced and released during sleep, providing a double dose of protection when you’re getting a bit of shuteye. If your sleep schedule is interrupted by a busy workweek or for any other reason, you should try to stock up on naps. Taking two naps that are no longer than 29 minutes each (according to NASA) has been shown to drastically offset the effects that sleep deprivation has on the immune system. Want a healthier heart? Sleep is essential for a healthy heart. People who don’t get enough sleep are at a significantly higher risk of cardiovascular disease and coronary heart disease – regardless of age, weight, smoking, or exercise habits. It is not abundantly clear why sleep is linked to a healthier heart. However, studies suggest that lack of sleep causes disruptions in underlying health conditions and biological processes like glucose metabolism, blood pressure, and inflammation. One of the reasons we know how vital sleep is to the heart is that people with sleep apnea (which causes them to wake frequently during the night) are 58% more likely to develop congestive heart failure. Sleep and mental health According to Harvard Health, sleep and mental health are very much intertwined. Those who suffer from mental health issues are more likely to also suffer from insomnia or other sleep disorders. Chronic sleep problems affect 50% to 80% of patients in a typical psychiatric practice, compared to only 10% to 18% of adults in the general population. Studies using different methods and populations estimate that 65% to 90% of adult patients with major depression, and about 90% of children with the disorder, experience some kind of sleep problem. Weight gain/loss It’s no secret that sleeping is vital to your overall physical health. However, studies have shown the links between getting adequate sleep and healthy weight loss. According to research conducted by the Annals of Internal Medicine, having adequate sleep (7+ hours per night) can lead to significant fat loss. Furthermore, those that get less than 7 hours of sleep will experience 55% less fat loss than those who don’t get their nightly dose of shuteye. Also, those who are sleep-deprived will face significantly less satisfaction after meals and lack the energy to exercise. So keep up your sleeping game while dieting! Concentration/ productivity Good quality sleep is the key to good brain function. While you sleep, your brain is working hard to consolidate memories and what you´ve learned throughout the day. It is also the time that your brain removes waste products from the brain cells enabling you to think more clearly during the day. In the brain of an individual who sleeps normally, the brain will show normal metabolism and blood flow to multiple areas of the brain. Without the proper amount of blood flow, the brain will have difficulty focusing, increased forgetfulness, lack of concentration, decreased problem-solving capabilities, short attention span, and learning difficulties. Remember that quantity and quality of sleep can have a major impact on your health and well-being!

content: TABLE OF CONTENTS Introduction & Context Outbound email subject (WIP) High Level Escalation email subject Introduction & Context In email communication, the format and appearance of the email is equally important as its content, as it will immediately convey a sense of professionalism and inspire trust, when everything is polished and aligned.
