title: System notes guidelines
content: In this article you will find the guidelines on how to properly leave notes in our tools: Magento, Fluent Commerce and Sprinklr. ​ Keywords How to leave notes; Notes on Sprinklr; Notes on FluentCommerce; Notes on Magento; System Notes; Notes guidelines TABLE OF CONTENTS ​ Why are the Notes important? ​ ​ General Notes guidelines ​ Notes in the Order Management Systems ​ Magento ​ FluentCommerce ​ Notes on Sprinkr Why are the internal notes so important? Internal notes are essential to ensure that we keep track of our customers contacts, requests and also of Emmies' actions, especially when these are connected to an order. By checking the notes done after a contact, one should be able to easily get an understanding of the customer's request, so that an accurate follow-up can be done. Notes allow us to know if a contact was compliant with legal requirements such as GDPR authentication , and help us understand what the customer's contact reason was, what steps have been taken to assist said customer and what is still pending action on our side or theirs. It is also through notes that our different teams at Emma, such as Product Quality or Logistic teams, can gain a quick and detailed understanding of a claim that was raised by a customer. With that in mind, and since Emma is a truly multicultural company, it is of utter importance that all notes are created in English , so that anyone, from any team, can easily assimilate the information included in these notes, without the need for translation (that would create a serious risk of miscommunication). As such, agents should also refrain from using abreviations , as these might not be understood by other agents or other POCs. ​ General notes guidelines Make sure to follow the templates mentioned on this article at all times when leaving notes; Be accurate and concise, inserting all relevant information in the notes but avoiding irrelevant or redundant things; Do not leave important information out: if you promised the customer a refund for X amount or if there's a new deadling for the parcel's delivery, this information should be present in the notes; Stick to the facts: your personal opinions on the customer should not be present in internal notes; And, finally, always insert notes in English. Notes in an order management system (OMS) ​ These notes are mandatory while handling tickets that involve existing orders, and should always be inserted in the original order . T he only exception being Fluent Commerce supplement orders that were created from a Magento order, in those circumstances, the OMS notes should be left on the supplement order in Fluent Commerce. Template to be used to insert notes in Magento: ​ GDPR: Y/N ("Y" if the customer was authenticated, or didn't require authentication / "N" if the customer was not successfully authenticated) TN: ____________________ (Sprinklr Ticket Number) ENQ: __________________ (Enquiry) ACT: __________________ (Actions taken and any Sprinklr flow errors encountered) Template to be used to insert notes in FluentCommerce: AGT: ___________________ (Agent's username, as shown on Sprinklr) GDPR: Y/N ("Y" if the customer was authenticated, or didn't require authentication / "N" if the customer was not successfully authenticated) TN: ____________________ (Sprinklr Ticket Number) ENQ: __________________ (Enquiry) ACT: __________________ (Actions taken and any Sprinklr flow errors encountered) ** Additionally, please note that FluentCommerce order notes currently have a 200 characters limitation. As such, if the agent requires more than 1 entry to leave complete notes, these should be divided into PT1 (part 1), PT2 (part 2), etc. IMPORTANT: When contacted by a third party, after the original customer has been authenticated, and the contact has proceeded with said third party, the notes on Magento / Fluent Commerce should reflect this fact. These notes should mention the original customer authentication and the fact that we then proceeded with the contact with said third party in question, noting down this person's name. Notes on Sprinklr Note: All internal notes on Sprinklr MUST BE added using the the "Profile Collaboration" section. Please check this article that explains the right process for leaving notes on Sprinklr. ​ Leaving notes on Sprinklr on the "Profile Collaboration" is MANDATORY in the following scenarios: ​ 1) Escalations, when escalating cases to other related teams (ex: Emma Internals, Supervisors, etc.). ​ TN: _______________ (Sprinklr Ticket number) ON: ______________ (Order Number) POC: ______________ (Person with whom matter was escalated with) ENQ: _____________ (Enquiry) ACT: ______________ (Actions taken) JIRA: ______________ (JIRA ticket number, if applicable) ​ High-Level Escalations This should be used when replying to the high-level escalation (HLE) ticket only. GDPR: Yes/No Ticket Number: ____________________ (HLE) / ____________________ (Outbound ticket number) Customer Inquiry: __________________ Actions taken: __________________

title: 2024 Public Contact Guidelines
content: T his article is only applicable for contacts made through public messages on Facebook, Instagram, Trustpilot and Yotpo. ​ Introduction and disclaimer This article is meant to act as a guideline on what we expect a reply to a public social media contact with Emma to look like. However, it is not meant to be seen as a set of restraints, but rather a platform on which agents can build upon. Our main goal will always be to have our contacts come as close as possible to an actual conversation between two human beings. Hence, why allowing agents to find their voice and be naturally empathic is so important. We want contacts to be fluid and personalized. Emma is a very agile company, so the agents representing us should never be (or sound) rigid. As Emma representatives, we want to show that we are humans, and humans are not perfect. We always acknowledge the complicated bits, so we can honestly and authentically give solutions. ​ Public contacts structure breakdown The four major dividers in a public contact are: Identifying the level of escalation Initial greeting and acknowledgement Resolution Closure Identifying the level of escalation Opening the contact and understanding the issue* Note : the levels of escalation are applicable to 1–2-star reviews. According to the user research, consumers use reviews to assess how well the company handles customer inquiries or concerns to gauge overall user experience and satisfaction. They look for the reviews that articulate the effectiveness of the company's unique selling propositions (USPs), including adherence to return policies, adept problem-solving and the efficiency of cashback processes. When publicly contacting the customer, we establish indicators of our service quality. Not only we try to create a positive experience for the reviewer, but also showcasing our authenticity and reliability for the rest of the consumers. We know that some cases are more concerning than others, and some customers might be more sensitive depending on their issue. Some of them might have tried to solve their issue with us several times and couldn’t, causing a lot of frustration. Some might have even contacted a lawyer to take legal action against us. And others might be frustrated with the product they received. All cases are important and should be treated as such. But depending on the level, we should take different actions and reply in different ways. Here is a quick way to identify the levels of escalation: Level 1 – Mild Frustration / Disappointment Level 2 – High Frustration / Anger Level 3 – Extreme Frustration / Outrage What is this level of escalation? Mild complaints about product or service quality where we can still turn it into a neutral/positive experience with the right reply and action. High levels of frustration, more damaging to our reputation and need to be sent faster to internal handling. Possibly longer complaints with more than one paragraph, use of caps lock, and mentions of other unsuccessful attempts of contact. Highest level of frustration that can possibly lead to serious company damage. Possibly longer complaints with more than one paragraph, use of caps lock, and mentions of other unsuccessful attempts of contact. Specific alarming keywords are used that can give us a hint that the customer will take some action against the company. How to identify the level of escalation? If any of these words are used: "musty smell", "sagging mattress", "disappointed", "uncomfortable", "discomfort", "generic excuses" If any of these words are used: "nightmare”, "joke", "appalling", "terrible", "laughable", “unethical”, “shocking”, “disgusting”, "shocking service", "awful company", "absolute shambles," "incompetence” If any of these words are used: "legal advice", "lawyer”, “fraud”, “scam”, “illegal”, “bankrupt” After identifying the customer's level, you can now act accordingly following the next steps. To show contrition and empathy, our tone shifts from more lighthearted to more apologetic as we move up the customer frustration levels. Our responses will also be lengthier at each stage, so that we can give customers the required information. The following templates provide a guide for tone and content, but agents should bring their own personality to their responses, as this will be more sincere and thoughtful. Agents are, however, welcome to mix and match the responses (always checking that the grammar is correct once they combine responses). ​ 2. Initial greeting and acknowledgement Being empathetic and getting the context* Note : always greet the customer; by the first name, unless the customer's username on the platform is a nickname. In those circumstances just use a generic greeting without using any name. Negative Sentiment Level 1 – Mild Frustration / Disappointment Negative Sentiment Level 2 – High Frustration / Anger Negative Sentiment Level 3 – Extreme Frustration / Outrage Direction At level 1, although the customer is annoyed, we can still showcase a bit of personality while acknowledging our shortcomings. This can help to ease the tension and build goodwill. Blue bracket : Summarise what the issue is. Green bracket: Offering a lighthearted observation. This can be about sleep (check our recent comms for more insights), contextual, or general. At level 2, we should apologize and show empathy and understanding by acknowledging the customer’s frustrations. Blue bracket: Summarise what the issue is. Green bracket: Paraphrasing the customer’s main pain points e.g. frustration, time consuming, hassle. At level 3, the important thing is to apologize sincerely and assure the customer that their issue is of the highest priority and is being treated as such. Green bracket: Paraphrasing the customer’s main pain points e.g. frustration, time consuming, hassle. Purple bracket: Assuring the customer that you’re dealing with the issue personally. Reply examples Hi John Sorry to hear [your mattress hasn’t arrived] . I’m here to help! We definitely want you to enjoy your Emma mattress, [which includes not losing sleep over when it’ll be delivered]. <— observation on sleep Hi John Sorry to hear [your refund hasn’t been processed] . I’m here to help! [Mondays are hard enough] without having to wait around for refunds. <— contextual observation that Mondays suck Hi John Sorry to hear [you aren’t loving your new mattress] . I’m here to help! [There’s nothing better than getting a good night’s sleep] and we want to make sure we pair you up with just the right mattress to do so. <— general observation Hi John I’m so sorry you’ve had to deal with this. I understand that [wondering when your mattress will be delivered] is terribly [frustrating and time consuming] . Hi John I’m really sorry to hear this. I understand that [you’ve contacted us repeatedly about your refund] and I can only imagine how [disrespected you must feel]. Hi John I’m so sorry about these issues. I understand that [your mattress hasn’t met with your expectations] and that must be [extremely frustrating, and uncomfortable]. Hi John I’m really sorry we’ve caused you [so much inconvenience and frustration] . Please accept my sincere apologies on behalf of Emma. [I’m looking into this immediately] . Hi John I completely understand your [frustration and anger] . On behalf of Emma, I really apologise. [I have escalated this issue with the rest of our team] . Hi John I want to start by saying how sorry I am for your experience. I understand that we’ve caused you [a lot of stress and discomfort] , and we sincerely apologise for this. Please know that [we are taking this matter very seriously] . 3. Resolution Being honest and sharing as much as we can about how are we working on the issue* ​ Order number not available: Negative Sentiment Level 1 – Mild Frustration / Disappointment Negative Sentiment Level 2 – High Frustration / Anger Negative Sentiment Level 3 – Extreme Frustration / Outrage Direction We can take a lighthearted approach when asking for missing information, so that the customer doesn’t feel like the issue is their fault. At this stage, we should politely build in the request for missing information as a vital step in getting the issue resolved. While reassuring the customer that we are doing everything we can to resolve this high priority issue, we must also ask them to provide the information so we can help them faster. Trustpilot reply examples I have requested your order information here on Trustpilot, could you please share it so I can look into this immediately? I have requested your order information here on Trustpilot, when you have a minute, could you please share it with me, and I’ll sort this out for you immediately. To fast-track this issue, please send the order information we requested here on Trustpilot. I have just requested your order information here on Trustpilot, would you be able to send it so I can look into this for you? I need this information to track your order. May I ask you to send your order information as I have requested here so I can sort this out for you as soon as possible? I need this information to track your order. I have requested your information here on Trustpilot, could you send it to me so I can track your order? I will do everything I can to put things right. Would you be able to send the info we requested here on Trustpilot so I can look into this further? I need this information to track your order. I want to assure you that this issue is high priority, and is being treated as such. May I ask you to send your order information I have requested here on Trustpilot so I can sort this out for you as soon as possible. I need this information in order to track your order. I understand how serious this issue is and I’ll do my best to resolve it for you quickly and satisfactorily. Could you please send the order information we requested here on Trustpilot so I can track your order? Order number available: Negative Sentiment Level 1 – Mild Frustration / Disappointment Negative Sentiment Level 2 – High Frustration / Anger Negative Sentiment Level 3 – Extreme Frustration / Outrage Direction We should provide a brief explanation of how we’re dealing with the issue and invite the customer to contact us on our main channels if they need further assistance. Blue bracket: Quick summary of what’s happened so far, including steps taken to rectify situation. Blue bracket: Clearly explain the steps that have been taken so far. Green bracket: Emphasize that one of the team has reached out. Send the customer an email using this format . In case the team have tried to contact the customer, so it should be highlighted in our response. Blue bracket: Clearly explain the steps that have been taken so far. Green bracket: Emphasize that one of the team has reached out. Send the customer an email using this format . Purple bracket: Politely ask for the customer’s preferred platform for communication. In case the team have tried to contact the customer, so it should be highlighted in our response. Trustpilot reply examples I see that [the delivery company missed you on Monday, but they will make another attempt to deliver on Thursday] . I’ve sent you an email with the details and next steps of your order. Please kindly check your spam folder in case you haven’t received it. It looks like [your refund has been logged and should reflect in the next 5 working days] . I’ve sent you an email with all the details. Please kindly check your spam folder in case you haven’t received it. You can definitely return your mattress during your 200 night free trial if you’re not happy with it. [Our team will be in contact via email to arrange pickup.] I’ve sent you an email with the details and next steps of the return process. Please kindly check your spam folder in case you haven’t received it. I see that [the delivery company missed you on Monday, but they will make another attempt to deliver on Thursday.] [We mailed you on Monday, but perhaps the message was filtered as spam? I apologise if it wasn’t delivered.] Please kindly check your spam folder, as the team will try to contact you again. ​ It looks like [your refund has been logged and should reflect in the next 5 working days.] [We sent you an e-mail  on Monday. I do apologise if you missed it.] Kindly check your spam folder too, as we will contact you again via email. You can definitely return your mattress during your 200 night free trial if you’re not happy with it. [Our team is on standby for the pickup.] [I see someone on the team tried to reach you on Monday via email to arrange this.] Please kindly check your spam folder, as the team will try to contact you again. I will do everything I can to put things right. I see that [the delivery company missed you on Monday, but they will make another attempt to deliver on Thursday.] [We mailed you on Monday and Tuesday, but perhaps the messages were filtered as spam? I apologise if they weren’t delivered.] Please kindly check your spam folder, as the team will try to mail you again. [Or let us know your preferred platform for communication so we don’t miss you or bother you unnecessarily.] I want to assure you that this issue is high priority, and is being treated as such. It looks like [your refund has been logged and should reflect in the next 5 working days.] [We sent you an email on Monday, and again on Tuesday. I do apologise if you missed them.] Kindly check your spam folder too, as we will contact you again via email. [Or please let us know the most convenient platform for you and we’ll contact you there.] I understand how serious this issue is and I’ll do my best to resolve it for you quickly and satisfactorily. You can definitely return your mattress during your 200 night free trial if you’re not happy with it. [Our team is on standby for the pickup.] [I see someone on the team tried to reach you on Monday and again on Tuesday via email to arrange this.] Please could you check your spam folder, in case the messages were filtered out? [Please also let us know which messaging platform you prefer, and we’ll contact you there.] Note: Whenever a user is voicing dissatisfaction towards Emma without a concrete reason, always try to steer them towards our Customer Service under the premise that we can support them better. 4. Closure Negative Sentiment Level 1 – Mild Frustration / Disappointment Negative Sentiment Level 2 – High Frustration / Anger Negative Sentiment Level 3 – Extreme Frustration / Outrage Direction We have already invited customers to reach out during the paragraph above, so we can sign off by thanking them for their patience and wishing them a good day. We should apologize again and thank the customer for their patience. We should also assure them that their issue is being resolved quickly and efficiently. In addition to all the information covered in level 2, we should assure the customer again that the issue is a high priority . Reply examples Thanks for reaching out, and for your patience! I hope you have a fantastic rest of your day, Hanna from Emma Thanks for your patience! Wishing you a lovely day further, Hanna from Emma Thanks for bringing this to our attention, and for your patience! Please have yourself an amazing day, Hanna from Emma Once again, I do apologise for the inconvenience. We’re doing our best to get your mattress to you as soon as possible . I hope you have a fantastic rest of your day, Hanna from Emma May I apologise again for the inconvenience and stress caused. Thank you very much for your patience! We’re doing our best to process your refund as quickly as possible . Wishing you a lovely day further, Hanna from Emma Again, we are really sorry that you’ve had such a negative experience. We’re doing our best to collect the mattress from you as soon as possible . Please have yourself an amazing day, Hanna from Emma Once again, I do apologise for the inconvenience. We’re doing our best to get your mattress to you as soon as possible, as a matter of priority . I hope you have a fantastic rest of your day, Hanna from Emma May I apologise again for the inconvenience and stress caused. Thank you very much for your patience! We’re doing our best to process your refund as quickly as possible . And we do understand how serious this issue is. Wishing you a lovely day further, Hanna from Emma Again, we are really sorry that you’ve had such a negative experience. We’re doing our best to collect the mattress from you as soon as possible . Rest assured this has been flagged as high priority. Please have yourself an amazing day, Hanna from Emma Replies examples that follow Emma's guidelines:

title: Empathy Statement
content: As you could see in our articles, more than selling our products, we want to build relationships and create connections with our customers, and for that Empathy is the must-have skill for our customer service. Maintaining positive fulfilling relationships means going beyond basic communication and polite thank-yous. And for that, we must feel e mpowered in our front line, able to address situations at hand and create positive and memorable experiences for each customer that is reaching us. But how? By putting Empathy into practice. Turn on your sensitivity radar, and start reading and understanding the customer who is on the other side of the ticket. Take your chance to create moments that will increase customers' emotional attachment to us. And as a first step you should have in mind is that every ticket you receive has a person on the other side that needs your help , feeling emotions that you may have the power to connect with and make them feel better. You hold the power to transform the interaction into an opportunity to make an impact. Understanding Customers Whenever you touch a case, you need to make it human. Question yourself: Who is this customer and what is his/her emotional statement? By identifying the customer you are interacting with, you can be prepared to deal with their behaviors and anticipate their needs, providing a personalized customer experience. To put into practice, let's simplify and divide our customers into 3 main categories, based on our customer's journeys and our main contact reasons: Now, let's list some possible feelings customers under the above situation may have: When you look at the person on the other side of the ticket and try to understand the feelings they have, you more than actively & sincerely listen to the person, you are also touching the human side of the conversation and by that, being able to empathize with it . Example: when someone is uncertain , as they are not sure if the order will arrive in time, or maybe afraid the wrong decision was made by choosing Emma, or even worried if the money was a bad investment and the product will not arrive, question yourself: how can you make this person feels better? What are the feelings that could transform this experience with us? Maybe making this person feel valuable to us, showing how glad we are for trusting our company. Assure we will deliver our promises and in case there is an issue we are facing, give the confidence we will find a solution as we value their experience with us. That is much more than just updating order status, is giving people an appropriate and engaging emotional experience . Possible opportunities: To build relationships, empathy is key. It's how we make bad situations good, and good situations great. We are excited about a customer checking out our products, showing joy over a purchase decision, and stating anticipation of the soon-to-come good night sleep on the new Emma mattress. Take into consideration that at Emma, we recognize our mistakes, and apologize when needed - but we use empathy statements as the main positive human touch by reinforcing and appreciating the customer's decision for choosing Emma. Turn on your sensitivity to read our customers, take the best of the interaction and you will feel empowered. Take this ownership and put your human touch in place. Take the chance to make an impact and make our customer service interaction a better place. :) Down load the complete version of the example above bellow. Training Deck Empathy and Acknowledgement png EmpathyStatementVF.png 1.0625648498535156 MB

title: Gained Understanding & Asked the right questions
content: Table of Content Active Listening Effective Questioning Investigating the information When a customer is contacting us, it is essential we understand the reason for the contact in order to provide a resolution. This article will help you to understand what is the best way to open a conversation with a customer and from that, take the proper direction to make an impact on the customer situation. Let's think in a practical way: With the right question in place, you can deflect a return and turn it into an upselling opportunity. Customers may not be aware of the variables that could be influencing their experiences, or what could be the right pillow to fit their needs. That's where our expertise comes in place, but for that: we need to listen to our customers . But, what is the difference between hearing and listening? Hearing is a passive act. It's about perceiving audible sounds with your ear. Listening , on the other hand, is trying to understand what the other person is saying and feeling. Active Listening Active listening is sincere listening, attentive and open. Able to reflect the content of the teller, able to reflect the feeling of the teller. We have different behaviors that you can demonstrate active listening that are essential for the customer, such as verbal nods, taking notes, asking questions, paraphrasing, and summarizing. By active listening, you will make customers more confident that you are there available, and willing to help. Plus, support you to avoid misunderstandings and mistakes, providing accurate and efficient resolution. Effective Questioning But let's say the customer is not providing enough information, or you may need to confirm if you understood what happened with the order of the customer. There are different styles of questions that can help you to guide the conversations. Techniques that can help you to control the conversation, they are the Open and closed questions, reflective or confirming and the probing questions. When putting into practice, the idea is for you to imagine your questions as a funnel, filtering the details provided by the customer and ending up on your pain point: the topic you need to resolve to make your customer happy. For that, you can always use the funnel technique. Investigating the information With practice, you will notice that sometimes, the problem presented by the customer is not always the root cause of the issue. As one example, the customer may call us saying his delivery is delayed and the root cause of this issue could be different reasons such as the delivery delay from the carrier, or delivery delay from our warehouse partner, or even delay from the warehouse not because of their capacity, but because they are out of stock. All of them require us different teams, and different follow-up actions, so it is crucial to find out the root cause of the problem. That's why every time we are handling a customer inquiry, we need to combine our skills with a proper investigation by checking all available tools & information related to it. Check notes left in the system by previous colleagues (any past contact from the customer/note left by another team - senior agent or logistic team?) Check order-related information (barcode status or related case information available) By doing so, you will be able to provide the proper resolution and make an impact on our customer experience.

title: Leading Interactions Efficiently
content: When we look at the customer service business and the metrics we have in place to measure our success, many of them will be related to t ime , mostly defining how efficiently we handle customers' inquiries. But why is time such an important metric for customer service? When you are contacting customer service, how much would you enjoy being transferred to different people to talk about one single issue? Or, how likely would you recommend a service that is not able to provide a response at first, and you would have to call later to have visibility of your order status? How about the experience of being put on hold, and waiting for 10 minutes in the line while you have no idea about what is happening on the other side of the line? Time defines your experience with the service you receive. But on the other hand, the question you should have to yourself when having a CS experience should be: Was your contact handled fast and efficiently? Did you get the answers you were looking for? Were you able to learn where to find information and avoid a returning contact for it? Was your time respected while interacting with the customer service? Those are some rules we should take into consideration while handling customer interactions: 1. Educate the customer whenever possible, educate the customer on any available channel we may have to avoid a returning call , for example, educate him to find proper answers in our Frequently Asked Questions, email or account, whenever the information is available. Empower our customers to self portal and have no reasons to invest the time calling us back. 2 . Antecipate procedures If the customer will need to send us a picture, provide already the next step indications, right directions, email needed, or information up-front. Anticipate needs by respecting their time. This will directly impact their experience with us. 3. Do not postpone information Do not avoid conflict or negative messages. Transparency is part of our DNA and avoidinh pr this will may manage bad customer expectations and take more time to an honest and necessary outcome. 4. Do not escalate cases when the workflow is clear Escalation usually has more negative impacts than positive ones. It shows a lack of decision and ownership of our frontline, open procedures and by the end, pushes decisions that usually are already in place. Be careful with customer expectations and the time you take to provide an answer to the customer's inquiries. 5. Hold etiquette Ensure the c ustomer agrees to wait in the line while you put them on hold in a phone interaction, or be clear you will take some internal steps while live chatting with the customer. Always thank the customer when returning, showing appreciation for the time waiting . 6. Closure question Always ensure there is no open question from the customer: "Is there anything else I can help you with?" Closure questions guide the customer through their needs and avoid a returning contact from the customer as you are already ready to support this customer with you. 7. Respect Closing time Respect customer time until the end of the interaction, ensure the customer takes enough time to end up the call by not rushing it to the end and negatively impacting the customer's experience with us. The closure should always focus on a positive feeling, as the customer will be motivated to reply positively to a Csat survey that may come after it.

title: Live contacts structure - Guidelines
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS Introduction and disclaimer Live contacts structure breakdown 1. Introduction 2. Information gathering 3. Investigation 4. Solution 5. Closure Engagement opportunities Things to avoid What to do when the customer is not replying What to do when the customer is being disrespectful and/or overly aggressive Introduction and disclaimer This article is meant to act as a guideline on what we expect a live channel contact with Emma to look like. However, it is not meant to be seen as a set of restraints, but rather a platform on which agents can build upon. Our main goal will always be to have our live contacts come as close as possible to an actual conversation between two human beings. Hence, why allowing agents to find their voice and be naturally empathic is so important. We want contacts to be fluid and personalized. Emma is a very agile company, so the agents representing us should never be (or sound) rigid. This article is applicable for phone contacts, chat contacts, direct messages on Instagram and Facebook. Live contacts structure breakdown The five major dividers in a chat and phone contact are: 1. Introduction * Opening the contact * On a phone call At this stage of the contact, the agent should: Greet the customer; Introduce himself/herself; Let the customer know they have contacted Emma + Country (Ex: Emma UK, Emma France, Emma Spain, etc.); Get the customer’s name; Offer to help. On a chat contact At this stage of the contact, the agent should: Greet the customer; Introduce himself/herself; Thank the customer for contacting us; Get the customer’s name (if this wasn’t already provided); Offer/promise to help. Notes: How the agent does this, what sentences are used to accomplish these goals and in what order these take place, all of that is entirely up to the agent. A lways greet the customer; by the first name, unless the customer's username on the platform is a nickname. In those circumstances just use a generic greeting without using any name. Key words: welcoming, friendly and helpful. 2. Information gathering * Framing the problem * On a phone call At this stage of the contact, the agent should: Authenticate the customer following G.D.P.R. (if the contact concerns an existing order); Gather all relevant information regarding the customer’s queries; Show empathy if the situation calls for it; Take notes, to prevent going back to the customer if the agent happens to forget something; Align with the customer to make sure everything is clear and that the queries were understood correctly. On a chat contact At this stage of the contact, the agent should: Authenticate the customer following G.D.P.R. (if the contact concerns an existing order); Gather all relevant information regarding the customer’s queries; Show empathy if the situation calls for it; Align with the customer to make sure everything is clear and that the queries were understood correctly. Notes: Agents should not be afraid to ask que customer questions. Until everything is crystal clear for the agents, they can (and should) ask the customer for further clarification. Key words: inquisitive, thorough and meticulous. 3. Investigation * Checking and verifying the facts * On a phone call At this stage of the contact, the agent should: Ask for the customer’s permission to be put on hold; Consult all relevant tools regarding the customer’s queries; Clarify any doubts that may have come up regarding the situation at hand; Decide on a course of action in order to assist the customer; Take all relevant actions (internal notes, escalations, etc) using our tools. On a chat contact At this stage of the contact, the agent should: Ask the customer to hold while we look into his query; Consult all relevant tools regarding the customer’s queries; Clarify any doubts that may have come up regarding the situation at hand; Decide on a course of action in order to assist the customer; Take all relevant actions (internal notes, escalations, etc) using our tools. Notes: Customers should not be holding for more than 2 minutes without the agent getting back to them. If the agent feels the situation will take a long time to investigate, the customer should be informed of this and given the option of receiving a follow-up contact later in the day. Key words: investigative, analytical and diligent. 4. Solution * Providing a resolution * On a phone call At this stage of the contact, the agent should: Thank the customer for holding while we looked into his query; Clarify what happened and (if possible and applicable) why it happened; Inform what was done on our end and what the next steps are; Set expectations regarding timelines (when applicable); Educate the customer on our processes and procedures (when applicable), in order to avoid repeated contacts for issues the customer could have tackled by himself/herself. On a chat contact At this stage of the contact, the agent should: Thank the customer for holding while we looked into his query; Clarify what happened and (if possible and applicable) why it happened; Inform what was done on our end and what the next steps are; Set expectations regarding timelines (when applicable); Educate the customer on our processes and procedures (when applicable), in order to avoid repeated contacts for issues the customer could have tackled by himself/herself. Notes: Clarity is key at this stage, everything should be explained thoroughly to the customer and we should make sure evertyhing was understood on his end. Key words: clear, structured and reassuring. 5. Closure * Giving an open-ended farewell * On a phone call At this stage of the contact, the agent should: Offer availability to assist with other queries; Thank the customer for contacting us; Bid the customer farewell in a pleasant way. On a chat contact At this stage of the contact, the agent should: Offer availability to assist with other queries; Thank the customer for contacting us; Bid the customer farewell in a pleasant way. * No signature required. Notes : On a phone call, if the customer is already actively closing the contact, we should not interrupt that to offer availability. We only offer availability to assist with other queries if there is room to do so. Key words: warm, available and polite. Engagement opportunities * Making connections * Opportunities: Agents should always make sure to adapt to the customer . Although our approach should be informal and fluid, if we encounter a customer that doesn’t respond well to this, we should change our approach to suit that customer’s needs (Ex: A customer that wants to be addressed as “Mr. Smith”, instead of “John”). Research has shown that messages that fit with a customer’s attitudes and dispositional motives are processed more fluently and evaluated more positively than incongruent messages. Always look one step ahead. Customer interactions unfold like a chess match. If we know a certain action on our end will cause a reaction on the customer’s side, agents should make sure to take that into account when planning their next steps. Providing context and explaining why things are how they are, will always go a long way. Transparency is key, if we want our customers to trust us. If a customer is excited about a product or a resolution, we should try to match their energy in our responses. On a phone call, intonation is key for this. On a chat, using appropriate punctuation marks and choosing the right words will be fundamental throughout the contact. During a chat, if the customer is using emojis and the context is favourable, or the situation was resolved with a positive outcome for the customer, agents can, in moderation, use emojis as well . This will act as positive reinforcement for the interaction and will enhance the connection between customer and agent. When using emojis, if, by default, the platform does not allow for full, colourful emojis during text entry, type Windows logo key + . (period). The emoji keyboard will appear. Things to avoid * Dodging communication traps * Things to avoid: Agents should always make sure to say and spell the customer’s name correctly . This is a huge red flag and will immediately convey a poor image of our service standards. Customers should always be treated with respect. Avoid repetition . Starting most sentences using the same words (Ex: We... We... We...) or using the same expressions multiple times (Ex: Please note... Please note...) will just reinforce the negative bias, many customers have nowadays, that CS agents are just copy/pasting templates. When something goes wrong, focus on the solution, not on who is to blame for an issue . We are one team, we should all be pulling in the same direction. Do not use unnecessary branding . It is fine to refer to products using our brand name (Ex: “Emma One mattress”). However, we should not be overusing the brand name on spoken or written communication. Negative reinforcement should be avoided at all costs . Acknowledging that something did not go according to plan is one thing, reinforcing the negative aspect of a customer’s experience with us is another altogether. Always try to focus positively on the solution and what we will now do for the customer. Information should be consistent. Agents should not provide conflicting instructions or guidelines to a customer. When asking for additional information from a customer, agents should always make sure they request everything they need at once . If we have to ask the customer for more information/pictures afterwards, this will just cause frustration and create the belief that we are artificially blocking their path towards a solution. What to do when the customer is not replying? * How to proceed with unresponsive customers * If a customer is not replying to us on a chat conversation we will send two messages: 1) After 3 minutes of not receiving a reply or message from our customer, we will send a message saying " [Insert customer's first name], are you still connected? ". 2) After sending the above message we will wait an additional 2 minutes for the customer to reply. 3) However, if after these 5 minutes (3 + 2) the customer still did not reply, we will send the following message " Unfortunately, since we have not received any message from you in the last 5 minutes, we will need to close this chat. Nevertheless, if you still need our support, please feel free to reach out to us again via chat or through email: [insert market customer support email address]. Thank you and have a nice day. " and close the chat. * NOTE : The above is not applicable at the end of a contact, when the agent asks if there is anything else we can assist the customer with. On that occasion, the agent should only wait 2 minutes and, if there is no reply from the customer, they should close the chat without further delay. What to do when the customer is is being disrespectful and/or overly aggressive? * How to proceed with disrespectful customers * If a customer is being disrespectful and/or overly aggressive agents should do the following: 1) After trying to calm the customer down, the agent should provide 1 warning: "I understand that this situation might be frustrating for you, and I am here to help. However, I must ask that we maintain a respectful tone during this conversation. If you continue to behave this way, I will be forced to terminate this call/chat". 2) If the customer accepts the agent's advice, the call/chat will continue. If the customer does not, and continues to be disrespectful or overly aggressive the agent should say "I am sorry, but given what I previously mentioned, I will now terminate this call/chat". 3) In case the customer contacts again after that and behaves appropriately, the agent that takes the contact should handle it normally. In case the customer continues to behave disrespectfully, the new agent should follow the steps on points 1 and 2. At this point it is recommended that the case/customer is transferred to a Supervisor/Team Lead. pdf EMMA - Live contacts structure - v1.1.pdf 1.29 MB

title: Press / PR Contacts
content: TABLE OF CONTENTS What to say if you are contacted by press (journalists and/or PR)? You are contacted by a customer that calls to vent and has no order with Emma What to say if you are contacted by press (journalists and/or PR)? You’re contacted by a journalist wanting to know more I’m afraid as you are a journalist and not a customer, I am unable to assist you at the moment. Please contact our Global PR team by emailing media@emma-sleep.com and they will get back to you as soon as they can. If they’re looking for updates on specific cases… I’m sorry, but I am unable to share confidential information regarding a customer’s order with you. Please contact media@emma-sleep.com and the Global PR team will get back to you. If they want you to comment on specific actions we’re taking to rectify the situation I’m afraid I cannot discuss internal policies and processes with you. I am here to help customers with their orders. Please email your questions to media@emma-sleep.com and the Global PR team will get back to you. You are contacted by a customer that calls to vent and has no order with Emma You’re contacted by a customer who just wants to vent I appreciate your frustrations and I’m sorry for any inconvenience caused. If you would like me to look into any specific details relating to your order, I can do that for you now. If they don’t have an order… I appreciate that you’re frustrated, and I’d like to reassure you that we are prioritising finding a solution to the outstanding process issues right now. However, if you do not have an order and do not wish to find out more about our products, I am unable to help you right now. If you would like to call back to discuss a current or future order at any time, please call back and we would be more than happy to help you. If they have an order but don’t want an update… I appreciate your frustrations, however as there is nothing specific I can help you with relating to your order right now, all I can do is offer my apologies for any inconvenience caused.

title: Transparency (Follow Through)
content: At Emma, we are honest and direct, and we openly address anything we need to. Transparency is about clearly communicating the course of action of a situation, and with that ensuring the customer is on the same page as you. Every day we are handling requests from customers related to orders. With time, words such as fulfillment , warehouse , barcode , and SKU become natural to our ears. Even the deadline for the order status to change from packing to shipped is quite obvious (when not facing an unexpected issue). But all those general knowledge is not the same for our customers. Perception and Subjectivity Perception is the way we interpret sensory data, but the way we do it, therefore, is subjective. We perceive things differently and we may react differently to situations we face. Subjectivity is how someone's judgment is shaped by personal opinions and feelings instead of outside influences. As one example, the judgment of a "delay" or the adjective related to it can be very subjective, as the example below: "Now that is fixed, the delivery will be fast ". "Fast" is subjective information as it can differ based on people's experiences. Plus, ask yourself, how much time means "fast"? 2 Minutes? 3 Hours? 2 Days? One week? And maybe ask someone else, what does fast means for them? It may happen that people perceive the time differently leading to a misunderstanding, simply because using the word "fast" gives no precise information. If you hear someone saying: "The difference in the price of this pillow is - affordable - ", you may face the same situation. Affordable to one person could be completely different from another. It is just another example of how the wording can impact the way people will perceive information. When handling customers' interaction, it is essential we provide specific deadlines and next steps as this not only gives customer control of the situation and clarity of what is happening, and how is happening, but also avoids a returning contact from the customer for something that could have been clarified before. But how to do it in an effective way? Transparency Framework The transparency framework is a supportive guideline to you manage customer expectations by being specific on what happened (acknowledge & reason) / the possible resolution and outcome of it ( solve ) / The clear next steps with specifics when and how & the following closure, ensuring all information was successfully transmitted with no open questions, in a precise and objective way (close).

title: Paypal & Disputes, Claims and Chargebacks
content: Introduction In this article, you can learn about the payment method of PayPal, about what are the differences between disputes, claims and chargebacks, and how to handle those cases. How to access PayPal Portal? The credentials to access the portal will be shared by managers and/or supervisors with the respective agents who are responsible for those payment tasks. Link: Access: Emma CS - Paypall - User portal General Information PayPal works as an intermediary between customers and their banks. A customer creates an account with the Paypal system adding to it a bank account or credit/debit card and whenever they're making an online payment, they can select which account to debit. All transactions are processed through PayPal, instead of the bank. When selecting Paypal while purchasing with Emma, PayPal proceeds the payment in our system and activates the order; and charges the customer directly via their selected payment method. Paypal cases Situations in which an unhappy customer who purchased with Paypal decides to have their money back will appear to our CS as a case to be handled with specific steps. After logging in to the Portal, the customer service team is responsible for handling cases in the Resolution Center at the portal, which concentrates the list of open cases . Open cases are payment petitions raised by customers to Paypal. After a dispute from the customer, Paypal opens cases for us to "respond" to the related claim raised. Our goal is to investigate the case, take a decision about the possible outcome of the claim and reply to the portal in accordance with it. The claims are raised for several reasons such as product not received, product claim, or even an incorrect dispute for the charge raised by the customer. Here you can check the list with types of cases related to PayPal payment that you may need to handle. Below in this article, you will learn about each of them with more details about the process. Types of cases: DISPUTES: It is a pre-claim process that allows the customer to open a dispute for the payment based on 2 reasons: not receiving item or item received is not as described. CLAIMS: Customer is unhappy with the outcome of a dispute and the case was escalated as a claim. CHARGEBACK : Customer or Fraud Victims reporting straight to bank / CC company to report the charges. APPEALS: Emma’s actions towards cases. IMPORTANT - Responding cases When handling a case, have in mind: Paypal is not a customer service portal, and should not lead to conversation or claim escalation. It is a portal dedicated to approving or not disputes and related refunds. Always attach related proof to the answers (proof of delivery, as an example). We are given 20 days to respond to disputes (open case will always have a precise deadline ). If we do not reply to the case on time, the dispute will be processed in favor of customer. We don't give discounts or compensations via PayPal portal. We just approve the refund of canceled or returned items. How to handle Paypal cases? Disputes In this one, PayPal does not intervene. The customer is entitled to open the dispute and it is up to Emma to investigate and provide proof and/or justification. If a customer opens a dispute they are informing us about an issue and a dissatisfaction with their Emma experience or product. We need to acknowledge their frustration and handle the case with empathy and accurate information. Time frame: Emma has 20 days to resolve the dispute with the customer directly before the case is escalated. Handling a dispute: Before anything, it is necessary to check PayPal's Resolution Center and verify the reason for the dispute: "Item not received" or "Item not as described". -> Disputes of "Item not received" Step 1: Investigate the order in the OMS to understand if delivery is delayed due to no stock, an order stuck issue or other logistic order; Step 2: Determine if the dispute is valid or invalid, and act accordingly: Reason why "item not received" Situation of the dispute Action to be done Delivery is delayed and item is out of stock Dispute from customer is valid : -> Emma is at fault and customer is entitled to be refunded. Respond to the dispute accepting loss. Order was not delivered at all (any logistic issue) and no longer possible to solve the case Dispute from customer is valid : -> Emma is at fault and customer is entitled to be refunded. Respond to the dispute accepting loss. Delivery is delayed and we have stock Dispute from customer is invalid: -> Emma has proof to respond to the claim and attempt to avoid the refund. Provide estimated delivery date and tracking link. Delivery is delayed and it is in shipping process Dispute from customer is invalid: -> Emma has proof to respond to the claim and attempt to avoid the refund. Provide estimated delivery date and tracking link. Order was to delivered and customer already refunded by Emma Dispute from customer is invalid: -> Emma has proof to respond to the claim and attempt to avoid the refund. Provide proof of previous refund and timeframes. ** Always provide any other proof (if needed) that is compelling evidence that the dispute is invalid. Step 3: If the customer is happy and accepts the outcome, the dispute will be closed. If the customer doesn't accept or is not willing to wait for the delivery, probably the case will be escalated as a Paypal Claim (that we will check later how to handle). -> Disputes of "Item not as described" Step 1: Investigate the details of the case by checking the order in the OMS, the items purchased, and if there is a logistic claim already placed in Freshdesk. Step 2: Identify if the case can be handled as a Logistic Claim , and if yes, proceed to offer a replacement. Step 3: After the investigation, proceed as indicated in the table below: Reason why "item not as described" Handling the case Situation of the dispute Action to be done Customer received a damaged product OR Customer said the product is not as described Offered a replacement and customer accept it. Dispute from customer is invalid: -> Emma has proof to respond to the claim and attempt to avoid the refund. Provide estimated delivery date and tracking link. Offered a replacement and customer doesn't accept it. Dispute from customer is valid : -> Customer is entitled to be refunded. Respond to the dispute accepting loss. Customer had indeed an issue but was already refunded by Emma - Dispute from customer is invalid: -> Emma has proof to respond to the claim and attempt to avoid the refund. Provide proof of previous refund and timeframes. Step 4: If the customer is happy and accepts the outcome, the dispute will be closed. If the customer doesn't accept or is not willing to wait for the delivery, probably the case will be escalated as a Paypal Claim (that we will check later how to handle). Claims Chargebacks Transaction ID / Payment reference You can find the Paypal payment reference (transaction ID) in the Order Management System (Magento) in the Payment information section. You can use both information available to localize transactions in the Paypal portal ( Payone Transaction ID or Payment reference ). In FluentCommerce: In Magento: Portal Home page After logging in to the Portal, the customer service team is responsible for handling the Resolution central, which concentrates the list of open cases . Open cases Open cases are payment claim s raised by customers to Paypal. After a dispute from the customer, Paypal opens cases for us to "respond" to the related claim raised. Our goal is to investigate the case, take a decision about the possible outcome of the claim and reply to the portal in accordance with it. The claims are raised for several reasons such as product not received, product claim, or even an incorrect dispute for the charge raised by the customer. If you click on " Show more " you will be able to preview recent pending cases; If you click on View all open cases you will be redirected to the Resolution Center. Resolution Center The resolution center will centralize the open and closed cases. Automatically, the open cases will be displayed. On the top, you will find the search bar, where you can search cases by: Case ID (Paypal identification number) Transaction ID (Reference number available in Magento) Invoice ID Name of the customer Email of the customer Case detail page An open case detail page will have the detailed information of the transaction; plus a section for you to respond to its claim. Detailed information section Possible Outcomes Each open case needs to be evaluated and you can proceed with the following outcomes: 1. Send a message When the dispute is not valid, ensure you Send a message including the reason why is not valid. 2. Add Tracking info If the order is on its way, you should add track info for visibility. 3. Issue Full Refund Confirm the dispute and proceed with the refund for the customer 4. Send an Offer To be used when the amount was disputed incorrectly and the refund should be a different amount. Use it to correct the amount.

title: First contact Resolution
content: Introduction In our effort to enhance the customer experience, we aim to ensure that our communications with customers are as effective as possible. Topics that are First Contact Resolution (FCR) oriented should be addressed and resolved as completely as possible to minimize the need for customers to engage with customer support beyond what is necessary. Note: Only applicable for the markets: UK; PT; ES Bellow you can find a list of Topics and sub-topics that are designated as First Contact Resolution oriented. Category (Level 1) Sub-category (Level 2) FCR Non FCR JIRA JIRA Info Details Product Information Dimensions x Tickets should be resolved when customer has received the proper information requested. Info should be shared if available. During peak season no exceptions should apply Materials x Color Options x Product Properties/ x Features x Others x Legal & Privacy Official Communications x Data Deletion Request x Cancel Marketing Communications x Data Access x Portability x Restrict Data Processing x Data Breach x WIMO (Where is my order?) Delivery still on time x x(UK) On Time : Tickets should be resolved when customer has been informed that the order is still on time and the right delivery date has been provided There's no reason to be following up on info not available Delivery Delay x x(UK) Others x Ordering Issues Discount code/voucher issues x Check-out issues x Others x Logistic Claims Damages x Tickets should be resolved when the new order has been created and the new order number has been shared with the customer (and the return has been created if applicable) After the 1st contact, when we have the pictures, case should be solved Lost or Stolen x Incorrect Shipment x Carrier Misbehavior x Injury Claims N/A x Product Claims Product Claim Category (Mattress, Pillow, etc.) x Tickets should be resolved when the new order has been created and the new order number has been shared with the customer (and the return has been created if applicable) After the 1st contact, when we have the pictures, case should be solved Services and Store Information Payment Options x All these info should be available on the same logic followed for product information Delivery Information x Returns Policy x Refund Information x Pricing and Promotions x Physical Stores and Showrooms x Others x Edit Order Update Personal Details x x Change can be manually handled by CE : Tickets should be resolved when the change has been executed and customer has been informed Change requires a 3rd party:  Tickets should be resolved when the change has been confirmed by third party and customer has been informed. If CE can do the update directly on the system, it's and FCR; if CE can't do it, a request to OM is submited and the case is closed. If the information can't be updated anymore, either OM or the Carrier will reach us with the info validation request Change ordered products x x Adjust Delivery Preferences x x Switch Payment Method/conditions x x Others x x Cancellation Order cancellation x x Tickets should be resolved after cancellation is done and the customer has been informed (informed of the refund timeframe if applicable) late cancellation: not an FCR RTS: suggestion to create a return and mark it as completed in order to trigger the refund. Currently: we create a ticket to OM to cancel the order and the the refund is processed. Either way, it's an FCR Cancellation Due to Delay x Delivery rejected x Others x Payment Payment Troubleshooting x Payment extension x Payment Status Discrepancies x Others x Invoice Request Invoice x Tickets should be resolved when invoice has been sent or when customer has been informed that the invoice will be automatically issued after the delivery. Modify issued invoice x Others x Returns Return Request x During this period and until further notice, return deflections are suspended Return request should be closed once the return is initiated Proof of return tickets should be resolved when refund has been triggered Stop return deflection (1month) Cancel return x Return Modification x x Return difficulties x x Proof of return x Others x Refunds Refund status x x Tickets should be resolved when refund is triggered and timelines are informed or when refund request has been declined. If customer is asking for a proof of refund ticket should be resolved after the proof is sent. Tickets should be resolved when refund is triggered or when refund request has been declined Refund issues x Friend referral x Price match x Retrospective discount application x Others x Others Spam Messages x Duplicate or Merged Tickets x Customer Feedback x Collaboration Opportunities x Others x

title: Sleep Expert tone of voice
content: Get more details abou the tone of voice here. Can be used for CS cases as well. Now that you are a Sleep Expert, it is important that you voice out the right tone and help customers to perceive us on the right way. The Sleep Expert Tone of Voice is a supplement to the existing Emma Tone of Voice. The Sleep Expert Tone of Voice refers primarily to mindset and responsibility. As a Sleep Expert, I am the expert in all aspects of pre-sales and return deflection. As an expert, I am aware of my responsibility towards the client. 1) The customer entrusts me with 1/3 of his life . I am aware of this and I implement it with every customer and try to justify it. 2) The customer is the centre of everything I do. That is why I always look at sleep systems holistically and offer the customer complete solutions. 3) Customers contact us because they have questions. We also have questions. Open questions, closed questions, alternative questions. We listen to the client - we don't lecture them. 4) I am the expert, so I appear confident but not arogant. The customer calls us and expects to be helped. We don't have to convince him that we can do it. Tone of Voice Return Deflection ​ With return deflection, it can happen that a customer makes an unfriendly appearance. 1) No matter how unfriendly the customer is, we always remain friendly, courteous and professional. 2) A customer has certain expectations that we have not met. As a Sleep Expert, I do not simply accept this and try to get to the bottom of the idea. 3) As a Sleep Expert, I know that I have the right offer for the customer in my portfolio, which I would like to offer the customer as an alternative. If the customer blocks twice, I handle the return as quickly as possible and offer the customer the most pleasant experience possible. As a sleep expert, I am aware that I am Emma for the customer at the moment of the conversation. That's why I try to convince the customer of something good!

title: The Emma Tone
content: As you have seen in our Vision & Mission: It's time to awaken your best article, we are on a mission to lead, disrupt and reinvent the whole sleep industry. So the question is, how can we ensure this message is perceived by the customer while having an interaction with our customer service team? Our Emma tone allows us to communicate with the customer in the same way across the world, connects our agents to the company, spreads our mission, vision, and our DNA, helps Emma to stand out from the crowd, contributes to our brand personality, and finally, creates rapport and brings loyalty . Take a look at our marketing campaigns above and check what we can get from it: We foster the culture of sleep and the benefits you get from it: "No more snooze button". We believe our products are key to awakening your best . We use proper colors, and positive photos, we choose our messages to help our customers to feel them, to perceive the message in the Emma way. Now, looking to the way we communicate on our social media as the examples above: Look at our approach when we speak about Sleep Science. We want to make a positive noise and bring awareness of how sleep is key to our well-being , or also show the importance of having a good sleep quality and how much this can be the perfect balance for our emotional and mental health. We talk about Seasons change impact, we talk about Daylight saving time impacts, World Mental Health Day, the impact of sleep during Covid, among others. We take sleep seriously. We are the Sleep experts. And how do we communicate with customers in our posts? Have you noticed some techniques? We are not robots! The key to feeling authentic is to talk human to human . We speak to our customers as you were speaking with a friend. We would focus on things they care about hearing such as how transformational can be a great night of sleep. We are familiar! We introduce our names and offer help. We call people by their name, we acknowledge our customer situation, and personalize our written communication. W e don't use overly complicated or inside jargon, we adapt ourselves to our customers: young or older, we can fit anywhere. We are friendly We are human and warm. We have a positive approach, always. We are optimistic and always happy to search and find a solution. We appreciate people coming to us and sharing their feedback. We thank people for trusting and choosing us. We are Conversational Our written communication has the same tone when we speak up. Our sentences are short and direct. Our tone is a normal conversation, informal but professional. We are excited about a customer checking out our products, showing joy over a purchase decision, and stating anticipation of the soon-to-come good night of sleep on the new Emma mattress. We are consistent across the world, and we use our voices to spread our DNA. See every customer interaction as an opportunity to thrive. Embrace our "Awaken your best" culture!
